38723473.review:
First of all I actually like this game a lot, which is why I am giving it a bad review. Let me explain. 

I really like this type of game, or rather these types of games. Rise to Ruins is, at its core, a mash up of city builders, survival games, tower defense, and God games. It offers a decent number of buildings construct and some require others to be built first which creates a good sense of progression.  If you are playing with monsters active, which you should be, you will need to create defensive towers to help the villagers or else they are all going to die pretty quickly. Everything you costs resources that need to be collected by villagers or energy which you can gain from various sources around the map. 

 Monsters are a serious threat if you are caught off guard and without a clear plan. They start off few and weak but quickly turn into swarms. Having a good maze of walls and defensive towers for monsters to navigate will become essential pretty quickly, and that is a good thing. Usually games of this type tend to be slow and leave the player with nothing to do for long stretches, not so much here. 

 The problems I have with the game all stem from the incredibly stupid AI. The villagers seem to be easily confused and will just stop building for no reason. Some structures require materials that have to be produced in order to be built. This means that when you attempt to build a structure but do not have the needed materials it will get as far as possible but stop until you provide the needed materials. Usually the construction will then complete according to whatever number it is in the que. Usually. 
 sometimes the game just fails to bother with a construction project, at all. This is particularly boggling when it is a project that DOES NOT REQUIRE any special materials. You can send a project to the front of the que, but that does not mean they will bother with it. The villagers will, instead, just keep building whatever they feel like building. This can be damning when you are attempting to rush the production of defenses.

 Another issue concerning villager is that death by dehydration is far too common. After creating several ways for the villagers to stay hydrated, including bottling facilities so they can take some liquid goodness with them, I STILL have frequent deaths from dehydration. If it is my fault I sure as hell can not see what I am doing wrong. I have plenty of water and yet my villagers insist on ignoring it and dying. If it is my fault then the devs need to add a note for the tutorial that makes it clear what is needed to prevent this.

EDIT: It turns out the water issue was my fault. I was simply not producing enough water and it has been brought to my attention that water and food values carry different wrights, meaning that you need more water than food. 

Monster AI can be a little daft as well, with monsters absolutely refusing to attack a wall if there is an opening somewhere else. This is forgivable, however, considering the difficulty of managing the hordes as is. You WILL have to face hordes of enemies too, make no mistake. Zombies, spectres, flame elementals and more will simply spawn and charge your villagers most nights. I found this to be a fun, if somewhat frustrating, mechanic that had me spending the days preparing for the night while also trying to meet the needs of my villagers.

 The issues that the game currently has are not game breaking but can turn a good time sour quickly when you suddenly have construction projects that are mysteriously unable to complete of you have 10-20 villagers die of dehydration in a single day despite having over 100 water that no one is even drinking.

I have faith that the devs will smooth out these issuews and I will gladly change this review to the entirely positive review I wan to give. Oh, also more keys for goodness sake ;)

38458454.review:
I played this game for around 13 hours before writing this review. 

The game is comprised of three parts. The most obvious one is Base Building. You have your villagers, they gather resources, build buildings, defend themselves against monsters and have their own set of needs and demands that must be met. This part closely resembles RimWorld, with the difference that you have no information whatsoever how everything works. Rise to Ruins seems like a game that wants players to sink their teeth into numbers, try build orders and ressource assignments, fail miserably and do better the next time around. Resources are stone, wood, and crystals, food and water all renewable in one way or another. You can dig yourself into mountains, assign prioorities to buildings and establish work orders. I can't stress the resemblance with RimWorld enough here. But compared to that, everything seems simpler, less polished. Of course I played Rise to Ruins in Alpha. It's difficult to establish several bases and explore the map, not because of the threat of monster attacks, but because it takes villagers forever to do just about anything. The AI isn't perfect yet either, with some of your villagers just standing around confused sometimes, eventually dying of hunger or thirst.

The second part is Tower Defense. Villagers probably aren't meant to hold up against hordes of monsters on their own, just now (Alpha) there are almost as much towers to choose from than any other building. Again, as of now, you have no wiki, no statistics. Yout don't know if it's better to build a more expensive tower or upgrade the cheap one you build already. Heck, you don't even know how the pathfinding of monsters work. Do they attack walls, or do they follow your "maze" ( I haven't gotten to the point where I could have built an actual TD maze yet)? It's for you to find out.

The third part is a kind of God Simulation. Those of us who remember Black & White won't fail to see the simliraties. Almost everything in the world can be turned into magic power that can be used to fuel magic towers, grow your crops or damage the monsters. I have to point out that this part especially isn't balanced out yet. At all. You can basically force grab all mosters on the map and turn them into even more mana in a big cooking pot. On the other hand, there are four offensive spells which all do about the same amount of damage/mana but neither of them is worth it.

What do I think about this game? It looks very promising. The think-try-fail-rethink concept already works. Too little information, inconvienient controls and (sometimes) seemingly unbalanced gameplay are an issue. For a game like this, those things are exactly what defines it's playability and long-term motivation. Rise to Ruins offers TD meets RimWorld meets Black & White. The combination has a lot of potential to make for a great game. Let's see if the developers can deliver.

38149231.review:
I recommend this game!

First things first though. It's a steep climb to start. Playing Rise to Ruins is about learning to balance and prioritize what is important at the moment. And many players will fall, slip and lose their balance. 

If you don't have the patience to dig in and look at what the game is doing and saying, this may not be the game for you. 

You have to manage your village and distribute your villagers properly accross a multitude of jobs. You have to have food and water to last through the tough seasons, and there are tough seasons. You have to have shelter to protect your villagers from heat and cold, the hot summer and the cold winter can kill by themselves if things get out of hand. And you have to protect your village from the monsters that come when it's dark. But you are a god, and can guide and act through divine miracles... ok, spells. When telling them what to build and where comes up short, the magic you can use can fill in the gap. But that's another layer, resources harvested and monsters slain yeild free floating essense that you can harvest. The happiness of your villagers will refill your essense directly, keep them happy and safe and it will fill faster. 

Individually, all your tools, the buildings, the defenses and your spells are not terribly strong. There is no overwhelming single button or single building solution. Especially the villagers, without your guiding hand, would be helpless. Learn to use your tools and the map around you however, and you can shape the world to your will. This game is about the satisfaction of learning to craft a thriving settlement. All the tools are there, but they expect you to learn them and master them. Rise to Ruins is not giving itself away, but is more than happy to be earned.

There are multiple difficulties. Peaceful, Traditional, Survival and Nightmare are the main settings. Custom lets you set the difficulty factors before the map starts, and the options are broad and potentially crushing if you're into that. Then there is Sandbox which lets you change settings and even the map on the fly. There is also a reasonably good map editing tool to make your own field of play and a small community of map builders as well.

The music is a nice background to the gameplay as well and lets you cycle through to the songs you like. 

The graphics are simple but I find them both charming and suitable. Although there is a wealth of particles, so if particles are your thing, WELL. Have I got a game for you. There are also small little quirks in this game that give it a fun charm as well, from moments like seeing the ridiculous names that villagers and dogs get, to things like a villager leveling up after mating (Someone really upped their game that night).

Disclaimer: This game is cpu intensive as you start to get into the meat of it. Its the calculations of wide range map alterations like the 'earthquake spell' and the constant decision making of the horde of villagers that will bog the computer down. If You're playing on a toaster, your enjoyment will be hindered. :(

If you got this far, thanks for reading, I've enjoyed this game quite a bit and I wish it continued success.

37819217.review:
[h1] Prepare-se para uma boa dose de [strike]frustração[/strike] diversão.	[/h1]

Esse é um ótimo jogo que mescla simulação de vilas e tower defense: Vários tipos de torres, muros e um número quase inacabável de inimigos.... E ao mesmo tempo em que se deve planejar sobreviver à noite, deve-se fazer preparações para o inverno - estação praticamente estéril - com trocentos recursos primários e várias cadeias de produção (minério ->lingotes ->equipamentos, construções), masterizar o gerenciamento de recursos humanos e materiais é o segredo aqui.
DICA: comece jogando pelo modo Survival para não criar maus hábitos.

[b] ASSISTA AO VIDEO DE TUTORIAL, vai te poupar alguns minutos de fúria. [/b]

No início do jogo, você tem 2 dias e 1 noite para: coletar água, construir fazendas e planejar uma linha de defesa básica nem que seja com 2 ou três torres e algum muro. Cada merda que acontece pode realmente ferrar com toda a sua logística... Basta a última linha de defesa ser penetrada (ou ignorada) que você pode acabar perdendo sua vila inteira! Por exemplo, uma árvore começou a crescer no meio da minha trilha de torres, bloqueando a passagem: só fui perceber quando hordas e mais hordas de zumbis rodearam a entrada da minha vila e começaram a me atacar por trás. 

NÃO DÁ PARA PRODUZIR ALDEÕES: se eles morrem, faz falta. Sua população aumenta naturalmente (mulher engravida, após algumas estações, o bebê nasce e os filhos crescem) ou por nômades (que são destroçados pelos monstros à beira do caminho) e também morrem naturalmente (de velhice). A sensação que tenho é que nunca tenho pessoas o suficiente para preencher os postos que preciso. 

DIVERSIFIQUE SUA DEFESA. Alguns inimigos são praticamente imunes a ataques físicos e atravessam barreiras (spectures) recomendo que os araste para uma lagoa de mana rosa para se livrar deles. Já outros são capazes de incendiar uma torre em poucos minutos.

TER SOMENTE UM ÚNICO FRONT inicialmente pode facilitar a organização da defesa, mas também pode facilitar a entrada de inimigos: torres com dano AoE são custosas e podem não valer a pena.

LIMPE SEU QUINTAL. sempre pense numa maneira de expandir seu território pouco a pouco e ir  destruindo os acampamentos inimigos. Após construir uma defesa sólida, fica muito mais fácil ficar acomodado e, realmente, uma grossa, sólida as vezes pode ser impenetrável pelo lado de fora, mas não pelo lado de dentro: existem muitos elos que podem simplesmente "desligar suas torres" incluindo linhas de abastecimento, transporte e produção de munição. basta algum desses estar comprometido que fode tudo. O que me leva ao último ponto: desastres naturais.

NÃO SE ACOMODE. O jogo é realmente desafiante e sempre alguma coisa pode acontecer fazendo você temer pelo seu cu, listarei alguns:
Primeira estação: fome, desidratação e nenhuma produção (só depois fui perceber que tinha que estabelecer uma meta de produção. Não caia no meu erro: ASSISTA AO VIDEO DE TUTORIAL)
Primeiro ano: depois de solucionar o problema da fome e da sede, aparecem 2 chuvas de meteoros, 2 terremotos e 1 lua de sangue (monstros começaram a cair do céu como num apocalipse, deixando os aldeões apavorados e incapazes de fazer outro trabalho). 
Se seus aldeões estiverem ocupados demais reparando danos de terremotos, incêndios, meteoros ou lutando por suas vidas numa infeliz e macabra lua de sangue, diga adeus a sua perfeita cadeia de suprimentos de suas torres....

NÃO JOGUE O MODO TRADICIONAL OU PEACEFUL, ELE FOI FEITO PARA SER JOGADO NO SURVIVAL. O jogo pode parecer absurdamente difícil inicialmente, mas tudo é aprendizado e cada noite e inverno sobrevivido é gratificante. Divirtam-se. O jogo ainda está em desenvolvimento, mas o dev é presente e vez ou outra tem coisa nova.

WARNING: This is a review for InDev 28c and this games updates a lot so maybe my review will be obsolete in the future. That being said I will write it half review half starting guide for the ones who are interested in the game.
As a side note I play this a lot in offline so my hours on record are alot more than what it says in Steam.


1º The game is hard, and by that I mean [b]H-A-R-D[/b]. You will be bound to fail the first time, do not despair. The final goal of the game is ruin your rising village (hence the name Rise to Ruins). Some might complain about starving and dehydrating, yeah thats a common issue there, unless you build first the [b]food and water buildings[/b]... so in order to survive more days you need to perfect your early building planning.

2º This games is a half tower defense for the time being. So the monsters will be quite strong in later stages of the game and if you do not plan correctly like building and improving the towers, and narrowing your entrance with walls you will have a very hard time defending your village. The monsters have resistances and vulnerabilities, so a varied tower building and improving is highly encouraged. Remember the ultimate goal of this game is Ruin your village. 

Aside tower defenses you have the oportunity to have [b]Guards[/b] (Villager Job who specializes on fending off monsters and patrolling) and [b]Golems[/b] (An entity made of essence that will defend your village and can be upgraded) both of them have a specific defense building that let us recruit them. I must note the guards and golems sometimes go full Leroy Jenkins on a monster horde, my personal preference is golems over guards but I saw fulfilling maps with a good guard regiment.

3º There are 2 main modes (aside difficulties) [b]World map[/b] (With a shared pool called Limbo for Villagers and Resources, and also monsters if you send them to that place, consider cleaning the limbo from monsters when you start a new village in a same World unless you want surprises) and [b]Skirmish[/b] that is basically independent villages that will only be affected by what happens inside that gameplay.

4º There are two RNG events [b]Disasters[/b] they can hit you consecutively, and range from an eclise to an earthquake (and a lot more) so be prepared for them while you play. And the appearence of "allied forces" that is [b]Doggos[/b] (Pet Dogs) who are neutral mobs and [b]Nomads[/b] potential villagers so they will be hostile with every monster mob (rescue them). The hit-rate of the harmful RNG is influenced by the size of your village, that also influences the appearence of the "allied forces" so in early game you will be mostly safe unless you are hated by the RNG gods.

5º Jobs, as I said before ther is Guard Job, but there are a lot more, every Job has its own building, yeah you will not full all the places in that job but you can change the job of the villagers if for some reason you lack manpower in that aspect. That being said the villagers sometimes fail to do their jobs due to 2 main reasons, aggro towards monsters and confussion and mainly due to the powers, and this takes us to the next point.

6º Powers, right now they are limited. They are fuelled with [b]Essence[/b] aka Mana this resource will recharge slowly and also with the drops from the living beings and monsters. This powers let you interact with the world. That being said some are lackluster and some are essencial to the survavility of the village. But still they need improvement.

-------------
Side Notes:

-The game runs in Java, so despite having that pixel look it needs a moderate specs computer. Because its JAVA!!

-The developer is quite active in the forums and he will answer your questions and troubleshooting he also makes roadmaps for future updates. Like for the version 29 the inclusion of a Shop system and overhaul of Storages and Farms.


With all that said, I hope you will be interested in the game.

This is a pretty good city builder/tower defense that has some unfortunate quirks that bear the stink of having been designed with community input at every level. There are numerous glurges that stayed in the final game because people got used to them. There's some serious inattention to the "end game." Numerous key mechanics function weirdly but go unexplained. 

Granted, the dev is *very* responsive and if you google a problem you're having, you're very likely to find a detailed explanation of what went wrong. Unfortunately, the answer is quite often "oh you played the game wrong; you'll need to start over." An example: Farms provide people with food, but if you notice that you're low on food, building a farm will exacerbate the problem, because the farmer AI will take the food from one farm and plant it in the new one, and you won't be able to harvest crops for a couple of months while everyone starves to death. The dev notes that you should really build thee or four farms before you do anything else, otherwise you'll never have enough food. It is now well-known within the game's community that your build-order should have a bunch of farms first thing, and now this problem does not need to be addressed. 

(Villager AI causing dumb problems is endemic to town building sims, and even Banished has one degenerative loop you can end up in. But Banished has *one* loop.)

There's supposed to be a full release soon, and presumably there will be a tutorial or an explanation of some core mechanics that wasn't present in the release I played. Hopefully, that tutorial will make it so that you can play this game and have its elegant systems reveal themselves to you in an organic way, because reading about those systems in a web forum takes a lot of the fun out--it makes the game more like assembling a piece of Ikea furniture than, well, than like playing a game.

In the chance that anyone cares to look at a negative review on a Very Positive game, I want to let you know a few reasons why you shouldn't purchase this. Or hold off on playing it for the time being.

1. [strike]The game is hard. Hold up, before you say 'git gud newb', I played on the Casual difficulty, and lost 3 people to starvation, immediatly after, I lost 3 more to dehydration. No matter how many water purifiers you build, no matter how many farms you build, IT WON'T MATTER[/strike] As of the current Uunstable 2 build, if the changes are kept, Food has become manageable due to more spaces in the Farm, and the Farm being upgradeable.

2. And this brings me to point 2, after you lose, 6, crucial, irreplaceable NPCs, you might as well reset the world right there, because you CANNOT make more/recruit more/send more. You have to hope, and pray, that RNG dictates that you will get a pack of Nomads that MAY join you, and that pack ranges from 4-6. Good luck if one or two more NPCs die from Dehydration or Starvation, because now you cannot make up for it, period.

3. The Monsters. The main things that are out for your failure. Why is this a negative point? You only see them if you have  the game on survival, or the one lower. It's a negative point because if you manage to SOMEHOW get past the Dehydration and Starvation epidemic, and you SOMEHOW keep ALL of your NPCs alive, including some nomads, you will meet increasingly stronger monsters as days go on. Their health scales, their damage scales, and most of them go immediatly for your defenses. And, they have damage resistances. And if you try to counter one type of monster, Jokes on you! Because the game is now going to send a different monster, and your defenses won't matter!

4. When I bought this game, I thought to myself, "This is gonna be a multi village God Sim...Cool! I'll start out with new villagers every time I start a new village." I was very wrong. You get a set number of NPCs, for the ENTIRE world. You will NEVER start with new npcs if you go to a different location. I get why they did this, it's so you couldn't farm more villagers to go to your main village, but you have to reset the world everytime that ONE village dies, and you lose ANY resources you collected. This game should be tagged under Rouge-like with how many times you have to restart, and how much stuff you'll lose.

5. [strike]Actual RPG stats. Now look, I agree that villagers should gain skills based up their profession, but what does my lumber jack need Intelligence for? What does my Water master need Strength for? Do these matter? As far as I can tell: No. They level up, but they still take their time collecting things as slowly as possible. To make a comparison of how this actually should matter: In RimWorld, a game I frequent, you set someone to Miner, and the more they mine, the more skill they gain, and the faster the mine, up to a max of 20. These villagers will go past 20 strength and 30 int, and still mine or chop a tree like their stats are 1.[/strike] The Developer explained what the stats do: STR boosts damage, hit points and physical damage resistance, DEX boosts work speed, to hit chance, dodging and movement speed, and INT slightly boosts a bit of everything (and later, will play into more scholarly roles, like learning, or improving skills faster.) But, I do want to flesh them out more when the skill system is added. ;)

6. Essence. I put this as a negative simply because the only 4 powers you will use, is Healing Aura, Holy Golem, Fireball, and Dissolve. There is simply not enough things to do with it. You can throw out a magic-damage only golem...That's neat...And then you can...Occassionally heal your villagers while they are fighting..But they'll still die by Damage over time the zombies put on them....If you're suppose to be God, how come you can't create people? You very clearly can call down fireballs to kill things, so what, is this the god like...a destruction magic only god? Why the healing Aura then? Things just don't make sense, you know?

7. The amount of villagers required to run your buildings. So obviously it's a village management, and like the City builders of old (Pharaoh, Caesar 3, Posiedon and Zues), it requires you to manage workers and where they go. Unlike the city builders of old, the workers required out pace the workers themselves, (Going back to my 1st point.), and you will never have max capacity at any time. Now you don't HAVE to fill these positions, but you will be scratching your head on why does the game recommend to build more then one building, if that building will only require more workers that you don't have to spare.

Is it bad? No, for some, this game will be a blast, but for the average gamer looking to step into new territory? Stay away. You will find yourself quickly dissappointed, and frustrated. The game (so far) is your standard fare of guiding a village of hopeless morons to prosperity and true strength, to the point you're literally no longer really needed, only there's god powers.

Since the game is VASTLY incomplete, I will say this game is absolutely worth the asking price, and it's REALLY fun.

However there are some thing it suffers from.

1. Survival difficulty is too difficult, and really only because A. the god spells mostly all suck total garbage in mostly every single way, and B. there's not enough structures yet to allow you some nice freedom without being inhibited and handicapped negatively, like by how the second farm type can't feed 125 people, even with literally 9 of them fully staffed.

2. Maps do apparently have a mostly-different difficulty curve associated with each and every one, making it essentially mandatory to start somewhere easy, unless you're just a badanoos at this game, and have the skill to survive in tougher areas without the benefit of just going back to another village to prepare for another try in a seperate, or the same region you'd failed in.

3. Spells such as Holy Golem, Dissolve, Earthquake, and Storm either cost too much to be useful, don't last long enough, or aren't effective enough.
Holy Golem can't 1v1 a zombie with 250 health if it has 300. This it kinda pathetic, since it's SUPPOSED to be a sort of divine god unit that can help turn a battle. It literally can get killed by 3 headless, since it degens health for some reason, which unequipped villagers can kill without problem.
Dissolve literally will never refund it's cost. It's supposed to remove corpses and resources from the map while giving you mana, or Influence, but it never has ever atleast gained me as much as it costs to cast the spell. However it DOES have a use as clearing corpses into essence for the purpose of fuelling essence collectors.
Earthquake and Storm take 3/4 of your influence/mana to cast, but neither can even destroy an enemy spawner. It seems like Earthquake should be designed to do this, since it's a large AoE spell with the highest cost, tied with Storm, which seems like a good way to thin a herd of enemies before nightfall, sicne it can easily kill most units instantly, or damn-near instantly.

4. Other spells, like Flame nad Meteor have VERY limited uses that can be on some vague benefit to you at all. Resurrect, which revives dead villagers if you click their ghost during ONLY Dawn or Dusk, which their ghost sometimes just never even appears, say they die in the morning, has a high cost, and roughly a 1/5 chance of just creating a zombie, instead of reviving the dead villager.
Flame is really only vaguely useful against low-health monsters like Headless, but like I said earlier, literally every can kill then in a 2 headless versus one of anything type of fight. The burning damage effect only affects buildings after 4 casts of this spell, which is less than 1/4 of the mana/influence bar, but the total damage of that many, is just pathetic, even if applied to enemies like Slimes or decent-health zombies.
Meteor can one-shot most units if they're not inside the hitbox of another unit or building. However they deal a slightly better amount of damage in an aoe, and can burn enemies after 4 casts in one location, but has as much killing power if not more than Earthquake or Storm if you use the entire mana/influence bar.
Burning damage is OP against your own villagers, so using them to help in battles is utterly pointless, and you'll most likely just kill your own people alongside the enemy, and every single person is needed entirely in Survival difficulty.

Ok just as a heads up, I got this game off of a giveaway, I never would have noticed it otherwise. However, while this may just seem like a cute little indie game that you'll pick up once then be done with, that was quite the opposite of what I have experienced.

   So to start off, this game a has a HUGE learning curve. You'll probably do ok until winter, only having a couple monsters attack, and a couple people die. That period soon ends. My first play through I was all over, struggled until winter, then died a horrible death. However, through that play through, gave me so much insight onto the game, my second play through went far better.

   The gameplay mechanics are fun, the heat, weather, light mechanics are all well done and provide nice modifiers to the game. The screen can get cluttered at times, but looks fairly clean until mid-late game. I’m a little iffy on the almost micro-management feature where you designate what to harvest, because I kept catching myself not having anything harvested. While being a little annoying at the start, you grow accustomed to it, and helps in the long run. Trying to manage resources was ok, kept getting annoyed that I didn’t have enough workers, boards, cut stones, etc. but I learned. (as I said this game has a HUGE learning curve)

   The defensive mechanics were a little confusing to start, I didn’t know which golems were best, or how many turrets, walls, moats, that I needed. I learned through time, but would appreciate a clear stat sheet. trying to expand without getting horrible destroyed by monsters was fun, and always changing.

   So in conclusion, I would HIGHLY recommend this game. It has its weak points, but that is to be expected with early access. The mechanics were fun, learning how each aspect worked was amazing, and kept me coming back for more. I learned to love the soundtrack, even though it would be playing the most chill music while all of my villagers were getting killed. They have an active discord, which has helped me learn a lot of the mechanics, and how to streamline my game. I love the feel of this game and would recommend it to all of my friends.

Rise to Ruins begins with an overhead map of the game’s continent, from which you select a region in which you want to settle your first village. These locations differ in available resources and, I think, climate, so choose carefully. (You can found multiple villages in different regions, but you only have a limited pool of villagers, shared between them all.)

After you’ve chosen a region the game takes you to the region map, from which you’ll play the game proper. There’s no real tutorial at the moment, but the game gives you some help in the form of pop-up tips. These are a bit lacking, though. For example, I had no food growth and no food, but nothing in any of the tips told me I should build anything until it was too late, and even then I didn’t know the best place to build it. An in-game tutorial would really help; the youtube tutorial video notwithstanding. Still, although you should be able to work out the very basics pretty easily, it’s a steep learning curve when things go wrong and you don’t know why. The Steam Discussions are a useful resource.

Anyway, you choose a section of promising looking land — water, rocks, trees, and wild food, if you can find it, are all good — and build a camp. That then lets you build other buildings, too, and before long you’re harvesting resources and growing your camp into a little village community.

知る人ぞ知る（？）神ゲー、ポピュラスの再来か。

ひとまずトラディショナルでラージキャッスルにし、敵モンスター数を残り５まで追い詰め
ました。
（サバイバルもなんとか行けましたが、ちょっと苦痛でした
　トラディショナルで遊ぶのが気楽でいいかも）
とても面白いゲーム内容で、これから先も順当にアップグレードしていくのならば、必ず良い
作品になると思います。開発さん、頑張って下さい！

Ｃｈｅｅｒ　Ｄｅｖ！！

ＡｏＥぽい街の構築手順を踏みますが、「神の人差し指」の使い方を理解すれば
神様ゲーになります。

街の中心を作り、周りの地形をガンガン変更して要塞化しましょう。
海は埋め立てて壁を建て、要らない森はガンガン壊しましょう。
木こりも大切ですが「最速でＴＤのキルロードを作る事」が何よりも大切です。

人間は死にます。敵に襲われて死に、飢えて死に、毒で死にます。
最初はガンガン飢え死にするので、メンタルが削れるかもしれませんが、
最初だけです。死んだ数の倍の新入りが訪れますし、リザレクトで復活も出来ます。

このゲームはアメとムチが効いていて「建築物が多くて人が足りないほど来訪者が来る」
という仕掛けになっています。
言い換えれば「来訪者が来ない程人が居る時は、食料の供給が絶対に追いつかない」のです。
なので、これは無理だと思ったら、とっとと忘却界（リンボ界）に送ったり、
或いは「鉄砲玉として、敵の発生する所に送り込んで破壊させる（慈悲は無い）」のも手です。

２０１７年１０月２４日のアップデートで、農場の中にも緑化魔法が効くようになったので、
多少は飢え死にしにくくなりましたが、システム自体は変わってないので、無駄飯喰らいに
食料を食い荒らされる時間が延びたに過ぎません。

ＴＤの要領でキルロードをうまく作れば、４つの塔程度で敵を止める事が出来ます。
街の周りをガッチリ壁で囲み、ＡＥタワーの周りをうまく回らせながら、
魔法弾の塔でスペクターを処理。
骨はマシンガン塔、残りは弓です。この他の塔を使っても勿論構いません。
敵を止められればなんでもＯＫ。

さて、ゲーム中は牧場ＳＬＧの様にのんびりと画面を見ている訳ではありません。

木こり、採掘、木の加工、石の加工を作りつつ、
エッセンスコレクターの塔をなるべく早い段階で二つか三つ作ります。
この塔の上にカーソルを置いておくと魔力が回復します。

魔力があるなら、緑化で食料を作りましょう。
魔力があるなら、あちこちから食料をつまんで持ってきましょう。
魔力があるなら、ファイアエレメンタルをつまんで海の中に落としましょう。
ＴＤのキルロードが出来ているなら、敵をつまんでキルロードに放り込みましょう。
０（つまむ）がこのゲーム最強の、神の人差し指の魔法です。
魔力がなくなったらエッセンスの塔で充電しましょう。

敵の数を少なく出来たなら、ゴーレムの塔を作りましょう。
木のゴーレムは魔法属性まで育てず、殴り状態で止めます。
石のゴーレムｏｒクリスタルは魔法を撃たせましょう。
このゴーレム達は「つまんで敵の発生地点に送り込みます」
しかしゴーレムは弱いので「付近に居る敵はつまんでキルゾーンに連れてきます」
魔力に余裕があるならホーリーゴーレムも殴りに参加させていいです。
人が余ってるなら、人もつまんで発生地点を壊しましょう。
メテオやフレアはまだキルロードが出来てない時のサポートに。
キルロードが出来てしまったら、もう使いません。

地震と嵐は、正直弱すぎるので使えません。
地震は発生地点を倒壊させるが敵は倒せない。とか。
嵐は敵を倒せるが、建物はノーダメージ。とか。
そういうのがあればいいんですが、現状は使い物になりません。


神の人差し指で処理していけば、敵の数が膨大になる事はなく、
キルゾーンを突破される事も少なくなります。
あとは敵の増強と城および街の発展の競争です。


農場の数は９つを目指して作るのがいいと思います。
１５以上あっても、ガンガン来訪者達が来て２０人ぐらいは
遊んでいる状態になり、勝手に飢え死にするのでコントロール
できません。

農場は水（泥水もＯＫ）が無いと食料が育ちません。
飲料水を保存する為には浄化施設が必要です。
水場の側に浄化小屋。井戸の側に浄化小屋。
ただの水は泥水なので、浄化しないと飲めません。
ボトラーは水を持ち歩けますが、人々は喉が渇いたら
まず浄化小屋や噴水に行くので、さほど重要ではありません。

惜しむらくは、建物の上限キャップが少なすぎて、殆ど大した街は作れないという所でしょう。
プレイヤーが強くなりすぎるのを嫌がったんでしょうが、町を発展させるゲームで、
街を発展させられないのは、かなり欲求不満になります。
ＴＤの要素も含んでいるのに、壁が自由に建てられないというのも哀しい。

このおかげで、現在はマップの三分の一程度しか支配下におく事ができず、
マップを制圧する事も出来なければ、終了条件があるわけでもない。
という中途半端な事になっています。

マップを見れば、木の無いマップや水場の無いマップなど、とても
面白そうなステージもあるのに、制覇できないのではモチベーションが下がります。
是非、マップの全域を影響下におき、敵の数をゼロにしたら勝利。
という様なダイナミック＋アグレッシブな勝利目標を定めて欲しいです。

これは今後のアップデートに期待という所でしょう。

This is a very nice Village Builder + Tower Defense game.

Pros:
+ the resource economy/infrastructure is understandable
+ assigning villagers to specific tasks is easy
+ the combat is easily viewable
+ throughout the game nomads will spawn, which become villagers -- great when you have population issues
+ farms don't produce (unless the weather gets warm enough) in the winter, I like this because its life-like, and forces planning
+ that 8-bit nostalgia
+ once you understand how to defend your village within the first year, each new village start gets a little easier

Cons:
- steep learning curve
- villagers can easily die to food, water, and zombie related issues
- the game has a lot of moving parts and is susceptible to huge lag spikes
-- during auto saves
-- during the start of the night-time cycle, because all the enemies are moving
-- when you play long enough to have a large enough village population and too many enemies left in the map
---*my issue started at 150 pop village with 400ish enemy mobs on the map
- graphics, 8-bit, if you want a really nice 3D village builder with pretty buildings and terrain, this is not for you

四回やり直して、コツを掴んできたところでレビュー。
AOEっぽいナニカ。

（恐らく）メインとなるモードではワールドマップから村を作る地域を選んで遊んでいきます。
地形は完全に固定ですが、色々な立地の地域があります。
プレイヤーは神となり、はじめに町の中心を建てそこから町作りをしていきます。
MPで神の奇跡（スキル）を使用することが出来、天候を操ったり資源の再生を促したり、資源・人員の確保から放出などもできます。
町作りで重要なのは建物コスト、町の中心をアップグレードすることにより建物の上限を増やすことが出来ます。
次には人員の管理、基本的に個々で割り当てることはできず、建物毎に割り当てて職種を振り分けます。
なので基本的に建物を建てないと職業が解禁されません。
建物はアップグレード有無がありますが、上げても人員の上限が上がるだけなので結局マンパワーなのが不満点。

・良い点
人員の管理が楽。
・悪い点
リソースの管理が難しい、特に農地の食料生産が貧弱で現状必ず不足する。
生産物目的だとどの建物を建てれば良いのか分かりにくい、エネルギーを生産する建物が分からない・・。
AIが悪い、サボっている建築職がいるのか人数の割には建築スピードが遅い。
水面でも敵が移動してくる、水が無限に手に入るという利点はありますが、結局少量の水場を残して埋め立てる方向になってしまうので水を越えてくる敵もいるぐらいのバランスで良いかと思います。水場は生成できないので。

悪い点の方が多くなってしまいましたがコンセプトは悪くないと思います。
半額セールの時に買いましたが、値段分以上に遊べました。
ただ現状では早期特有のバランスの悪さが目立ちました。
特にスキルを限り、食糧事情がどうにもならないのでそこの改善が望まれます。
スキル有りきと言われてしまえば納得しますが、初心者ではMPの管理までするのは難しいかなと思います。

10\27更新
調整が入ったのかFarmのガン建てすることにより食料事情はどうにかなった。
が、今度は水が枯渇し始めて崩壊した。
必要人数に対しての資源供給が釣り合って無いゲームバランス、内政すると防衛に回す人員居ないのでタワー必須。
ただし、やたら人がふらついて死ぬ事やモンスターの進行方向を制動し難いことからタワーガン建て推奨。
また戦闘を指示できないので戦士が来るのが間に合わずに建物が壊れることがしばしば。
人は基本的に増加傾向にあるので、調整したい場合は神パワーで異次元ストレージ行きにしないといけない。

とりあえず水不足は致命的で、海の無いMAPだと食料か水かの二択で死ぬことになる。
神パワーでも雨は降らせないので水は一番重要なのかもしれない。

10\29

戦士は相変わらず要らず、バリスタ以外のタレットは建てる必要なし。
とはいえ水を海から入手していたのでこれが陸地で村を作る場合は大分キツイのかもしれない。
村が安全になったが今度はエンディングが見つからない・・・。

35837796.review:
An enjoyable game to play and come back to every so often. It has its challenges to begin with but it becomes relaxing after a while, unless you don't want it to be.

This game you are looking at playing is a village sim with a tower defence aspect and some godly powers thrown in. You can use these godly powers as you see fit getting more energy by harvesting the [strike] souls[/strike] essence of those that die eventually getting to a point where you have buildings that collect and store the essence and create it from refined crystal to give you unlimited power! I like creating little stories for those who i see fit to use my power on in my village such as how the others would think when you send one of them to limbo or have a field of  potatos appear before them or a sudden strom appear above their heads, [b] Ill use it in my village if I want to! [/b] They all have their own names and stats as well so you can track them down and bring the ones you like with your godly powers to the new areas and have them help in your dominion of it.

The buildings have your few typical resource collections such as wood, rock and minerals (iron). These can be refined to let you further expand and upgrade your village. Then you also have to worry about food and water. The changes in season make it so there is a constant need to change how many workers are assigned to these essentials. The constant influx of villagers as well adds to this making it a challenge to get enough food for the winter season, and water for the summer. If you place them in the wrong spot as well it is relatively easy to break them down and move them, but upgrading them back to where to max level can take a little while. Luckily they are still useable even when upgrading.

Then you add the tower defense side to this, basically as long as you have the resources you are free to build the walls and towers how you like and you honestly don't need too much to defend early on but as the monster develop their own little villages (spawns) more attack. The towers are upgradable and the different types of them lets you choose how best you want to set up. Such as forcing monster down a narrow corridor and hitting them with spread damage or creating you own army of golems to fight them off. It is great how they use the different resources as well so you can set up a huge mining, wood or magic facility and use the resources from it to supply those towers with ammo, but it will mean you are stuck with only certain towers.


[u] TL:DR: [/u]
[list]
[*] A world map that lets you choose the area you want to begin.
[*] Godly powers to smite those chatter boxes and the monsters that dare defy you or help you villagers get more food and finish work quicker..... I guess..... 
[*] Buildings allow for you to develop slowly and aren't punishing if you make the wrong one just tear it down and get the resources back.
[*] Tower defense aspect is different and fun, but start with understanding the village side first and aim  to build some golem combulators first is my suggestion, just remember you need an essence collector.
[*] Even if you mess up you can always just start again, without having to go through much and the maps won't change allowing for you to learn how to start out pretty easily and then getting harder by having you choose what you bring to the new areas from your villages.
[/list]

This game is boring as hell. You're basically going to sit watching villagers chop wood for hours and not be able to do anything else because you are unable to expand. 

The reason being is that your population will basically never grow. Villagers won't reproduce unless they're assigned to doing nothing. Plus, after you do make a baby, it takes about three game days for it to grow up and enter the labor force, which turns out is quite a long time. 

Every building requires a dedicated workforce. You start with 40 villagers, so fine. You will have enough free villagers to assign them to work in your first buildings—say, a lumber mill. But the more you build—which you will want to do because you're going to want a population that is well fed and watered and well armed—the more you get spread thin. So then if you lose a villager to fighting zombies, you may well have lost the only person that smelts ore for all you know or who makes arrows for the ballistae.

You also don't really get nomads adding to your population from the outside. As game events go, notifications of nomads in the area are few and far between. Plus, after day four or so, it's unlikely they'll even be able to make it to your base because there will be so many graveyards and monster spawns on the map that they'll probably be killed en route with nothing you can do about it.

Plus, there's a fairly ungenerous building cap that requires you to continually expand your city center before you can add more buildings. Meaning more waiting and boredom while you watch your dwindling number of villagers chop wood. Your villagers are also very dumb. They will go all the way across town to chop wood instead of chopping the wood you've assigned right next to them/the building you told them to build. Also, don't try and build more than one structure at a time because they are so addlebrained that they will start one structure, get halfway through completing it, then go to the next one and start it until it's halfway done, then go back to the first one. I mentioned in the review that the game crashed for me and the dev contacted me (see comments) within an hour or so. I know indie devs fear negative reviews like the plague, but it's still nice to get instant help. But seeing that the game was released into EA in october 2014, it kinda left me with a feeling that the dev is more concerned about the negative reviews than finishing the game. Now I just bought the game and haven't been observing the pace of the development, so I might be completely off with that (and I hope I am). I also took a quick glance at the steam forums and it seemed like the dev was actually active there too (which is surprisingly rare).


Thoughts about the actual gameplay after 10 hours:

+The pace of the game seems good. Doesn't require reflexes like a RTS would, but also doesn't make you just sit and wait too much.
+In general it shows potential and implies that it has depth and replay value.
+For the most part the UI is clear and easy to use.

+-The lack of in-game tutorial. There is a button for "Watch a tutorial video" and the game gives you some general tips along the way, but they help very little.

-The game offers too little information about things like how many buidlings you need to have in order to have your town survive (farms for food, wells or rain catchers for water etc).
-The time for pixel graphics has come and gone. It actually gets extremely blurry if you zoom in even a little bit (why does it even allow you to do this?).
-The villagers' AI is sometimes bugged and not knowing what their priority is in performing different tasks takes a lot of the fun out of the game.
-Some of the buttons on the UI (assigning villagers to different buildings for example) are WAY too small, considering the next point.
-The mouse pointer moves like it's on a rubber band. The delay ain't that bad, but just enough that it actually gets really annoying to try and aim at some of the smaller buttons.

It's these last two points that made my review negative. Feels like something that wouldn't bother a normal person, but some of the buttons are really small and the rubber banding mouse ain't helping.

And in case anyone gets to read this before the fanboys downvote this into oblivion (as they do to all negative reviews): I'm not saying not to buy it. But I am suggesting to keep an eye on the development for a while before doing so.

Ok this one deserves a full review.
It's a very decent game oscillating between a colony builder and a god game. 

Pros:
+ Complete and complex colony builder, which in itself is pretty rare.
+ Lots of content, game modes and yet feels appropriately balanced
+ Cute art style, it's not earth shattering but it does its job and has a certain charm to it
+ Features a decent tutorial and hint system teaching you the basics, it's far from perfect of course, but it's there.
+ Actively developed and regularly updated

Cons
+ The user interface while not being attrocious feels more like a developer debug menu than a polished thing. It's serviceable, but counter intuitive, requiring more clicks than necessary and where information isn't displayed sufficiently/efficiently.
+ The "mana" system allowing you to spawn pretty much any resource or use powers feels like a placeholder for features / buildings / tech that have yet to be implemented.
+ the whole turret / combat /military side feels a bit weak.

All in all it's a very interesting game in a fairly niche genre. It's not without flaws but nothing game breaking. For that price, it's definitely recommended.

ise to Ruin has earned a stronger place in my heart and my steam library than I expected when I picked it up. While it's not perfect, there is a charm and love in the game that makes me want to keep it installed and play a bit every update.

	The music and pace of the game play can be very relaxing. While it can be very challenging to try and get the village up and running with the pressure of monsters trying to ruin all your hard work, the game itself has a very strong ant-farm feel. The villagers just do their things with little to no intervention from you; assign jobs and build or harvest orders, watch them scurry around to take care of the village. It can almost be therapeutic to just zoom out and watch them move about while listening to the music.
	It is a god game, so there is a bit of messing around. Between god powers, sandbox mode, and custom difficulties, I have enjoyed a fair amount of just screwing off and either toying with my villagers or breaking the game engine by testing special tower and maze arrangements then spawning more mobs than my computer could handle.

	Admittedly, this game will not have a universal appeal. As of right now, there isn't any designated objective or overarching goal involving the world map. The players will have to decide what they are in for: take over a map and safely grow a village as large as they can, fight off hordes of enemies in harder difficulties, or try and populate all parts of the world map with sustainable villages. If you don't think you can sorta make your own goals through things like this or the custom difficulty options, you may want to watch and wait. Content is constantly being worked on, so there may be something that appeals more to you later on.
	
	For those of you wary of Early Access, there is something to be said about the developer; while this is by no means unique, Rayvolution is very active with the community and passionate about the game. I've been on the Rise to Ruin Discord server (you can find a link in the main menu of the game) and have enjoyed conversation with him and other players immensely. I have faith that Rayvolution will see the game continue to grow in quality and content, and not leave RtR in Early Access hell. If you are interested in the game, but don't want to buy it, I'd highly recommend you chat with him and the other fans there.

그런고로 현 단계에서는 신의 힘은 어디까지나 도시 경영에 보조적인 능력으로 사용하게 되므로, 현 단계의 이 게임은 도시 건설/경영 게임이라고 생각하는 편이 속편할 수 있습니다. 또한 아직 계획된 많은 요소들이 개발중 단계에 있기 때문에 현재로서는 "갓-라이크 도시 건설/경영 타워디펜스 게임"이라고 생각하시면 되겠네요. 다음 업데이트 컨텐츠로 가드 패트롤 시스템이 추가되기 전인 지금은 디펜스 타워를 건설하고 입구를 미로화하는 말그대로 타워 디펜스 게임의 요소가 강제되고 있습니다.

게임 모드로는 스커미쉬/월드맵 모드가 존재하고, 그 월드 맵 모드 에서는 준비된 여러 지형지점들 중 하나를 선택해서 거기서 도시를 만드는 것부터 시작해, 완성된 도시에서 남아도는 자원이나 시민들을 천국(limbo)에 저장해두고 월드맵의 다른 곳에서 다른 도시를 계발할 때 꺼내다 투입해 쓰는 것이 가능한 방식입니다. 스커미쉬 모드는 말 그대로 스커미쉬 모드.

또한 난이도 모드는 다양하게 준비되어 있어서 간단하게 말하면 피스풀, 노멀, 서바이벌, 샌드박스 모드등이 준비되어 있다고 할 수 있으니 시뮬레이션 게임으로서는 이미 부족함 없는 즐길거리들이 준비되어 있습니다. 위에서 말한 '신의 힘 치곤 좀 약한듯' 한 점도 샌드박스 모드라면 에센스를 무제한으로 쓰면서 플레이할 수 있는 등등. 또 맵 에디터 자체도 준비되어 있습니다.

I do feel that quality is a big deal to the 1-man devellopment studio that is SixtyGigs Games.

The gameplay is a blend of city builder/colony survival and God games, if you want references, I think the game is inspired from the first Black&White from LionHead Studio, wich is my favorite God game.
My favorite part is the god powers, being able to interract with the world in real time by your own hand or via magic powers, doesn't feel broken of overpowered, but just fine as it is implemented.

For the moment the "defense" aspect of the game is heavily reliant on the "tower defense" type, but next update will provide the possibility to have patrol of armed citizen, I'm really looking forward to this.

The music soundtrack is great and as the devellopment progress SFX caused by gameplay element are becoming more and more complete and immersive.


I don't like much making a list of pro and con, especially in a game that please me, so I'll just underline the major positive and negative point.

Positive one:
The gameplay doesn't feel limited, it's not the kind of game where once you build every building you feel as if you played the whole game.
That's the kind of game that make you think, think about how to play more efficiently, and not necessarily in an unique fashion: you can devellop your own way of playing, and don't have to adopt "One uber-way of doing things" that would soon be written down in a guide, that every lazy people would then apply all along in the game.
If you want examples of what I'm tring to put in word: You have a lack of food, you have several way to resolve the situation: You can either assign more workers to the farm, build a more efficient farm that need less workers, you can use your powers to make the naturals fields of whatever you're growing, or you can even gather the food yourself with your own divine hand. And thoses choices apply for everything: wood/ water/stone/crystals ressources, defense against enemies, health care etc...

Negative one:
I do think the "tower defense" aspect to be a bit limiting as way of defence and also breaking realism.
Not in a very bad way tho, tower defense in this game is fun, but while your villagers can defend themselves to a certain extend against sparse monsters, after some days it's no longer a viable way at all, and you need to place towers and make a labyrinth out of walls to be able to survive (there are several level of difficulties mind you, so there may be a sweet spot between the tower-defense and the totally peacefull mode.)
BUT:
Next update will provide the ability to create patrols, sparring between citizen, watchtowers, and guard houses for them and their equipement, so it may become a viable way to defend your town the dwarf-fortress way (with your own citizens, trained for combat). 

I'm really eager to see what the next update will bring, as this game really feel promising!

I've had this game for all eternity, and just now realized that I haven't written a review for it. So here goes:

Rise to Ruins (or Retro-Pixel Castles, if you're an old-timer) is a crazy mix of town-building, sandbox survival, and tower defense. It's not a terribly easily game to pick up, but it's not anywhere near the most difficult I've ever played. It is in nearly constant flux, because the one-man development crew works on this game nonstop. New features and major game-changing elements come up once every few months, and they all add something useful to the game. That being said, the difficultly from one version to the next can fluctuate a little bit (much more in the earlier builds than now).

There's a crapton of maps to choose from, and every map has at least two good spots to start building the town camp from. There's as much variability as you could reasonably want, between the maps, the weather, and the variable monster spawns. So yeah. Make a town, gather food and water, and build up walls and towers. Or skip the tower defense and make masses of combobulators, and watch your stone and wood army of golem demolish everything in their path. Most important of all, don't die.

Good luck.

32573439.review:
TL;DR: Buy this game, it's amazing and fun.

Long review:
I bought the game as a birthday gift to myself and am incredibly pleased. It's fun, entertaining, and has more depth than you might suspect. The art style is simple and clean. Game play is simple to learn while offering great challenge.

Resource management is efficient: Wood, Stone, Food, and Crystals are the basic four to be gathered from the map. They can each be refined into secondary, advanced resources.

Your citizens are not directly managed other than being able to pick them up and move them around. They operate by AI based on how you manage your village development. This saves a lot of click and drag that bogs down other titles. It was a great design choice. Citizens also level up based on their work, becoming more efficient and stronger over time.

Your village succeeds or fails based on your method of developing it, and defending it. Monsters will start attacking your village within a few days of starting it. The game brings in aspects of RTS games and Tower Defense as your primary combat systems. Much of your defense is managed by tower construction and building obstacles to slow the advance of attacking nasties.

The game can be played in settings from Sandbox mode to Nightmare mode, meaning from "no monsters" to "Do you feel lucky, punk?" The hardest level can pose a challenge to the most advanced village-building gamer.

The game is not complete, but updates are frequent. The developer is present on the Steam forums and hosts Twitch streams to keep players up to date with development. He's also very interactive with the player base and open to new ideas. This is the kind of developer who keeps improving the game and providing new content on a regular basis. Check in on his streams, you'll like the guy and his video-bombing cat.

I give this game a 10/10 because it's great as is, getting better all the time, and the developer is a fantastic example of how to conduct business when creating a game.

32490153.review:
Fantastic "little" village survival game. The developer steadily brings out updates with brand new content, with a massive "defence" patch (2nd June 2017), allowing upgrades of defence positions, in addition to all the other upgradeable buildings.

The visuals are crisp and satisfying to look at, with everything from colors and shape of everything falling properly into place, and several varieties of every tile-set, apart from water. There is a world map where you can choose any map to visit to look at this variation; blue forests to ashen sands, and marble mountains to blackstone.

After choosing a map on the world screen, you start off the game on an uninhabited map, prompting you to place your village center where you want it to be. Taking a close look at the map for a minute or two can make things much harder or easier depending on location. Shortly afterwards you start to notice the myriads of buildings at your disposal, and work you have to do in order to survive; it might be overwhelming at first, but it really is quite simple once you get going:
- Select resources for collection.
- Build stuff you need: Collection buildings for wood/stone etc, production, defences, refining, etc etc.
- Don't die!
- Repeat.
You cannot control villagers directly, however. They will do the jobs that are given to them via the resources you select and the job list UI on the left side of the screen. This is somewhat a weak point, as the control you have is extremely low. I would like to have something of a flag system; where you can place flags at certain locations that works like additional orders to your villagers. Like flags for avoiding areas, prioritizing resource collection at a certain area so you don't have to reassign those orders all the time. or even attacking an area. The Avoid Area flag would be great, as villager AI is very bad when they fight monsters, often dying for no reason when they could run away into their houses to heal. The AI is the game's biggest weakness, but really is not a big issue.

The gameplay is affected by several factors. Weather and seasons play a huge role. If it's windy and rainy, your villagers gets slowed down significantly. It does not rain in the winter and nothing grows, and in the summer villagers drink more water and heat up frequently. It's a lot to take into consideration. Luckily, you have several spells to use! Your spell points regenerate over time and from particles floating around the map after something has died, and can be spent to cast storms, picking things up, quickly growing nature stuff, healing and more. Be careful where you cast that fireball though!


You are probably gonna fail spectacularly the first times around, unless you picked the easiest difficulties at the world screen.  Either way it's a good time, and really satisfying to build your favorite village. The game is very cheap for what you get for it, the replayability is immense, and increased by several magnitudes by the map editor and ability to share maps over the workshop. Enjoy!

32388451.review:
The compelling element of gameplay: increasing building technology requirements (i.e. materials) to allow a larger number of buildings.

That little game mechanic drives the whole game, blocking new buildings from coming up until prerequisite buildings have been placed and required materials are available. It is implemented by requiring the city center to get upgraded, and each subsequent upgrade requires new materials that must be manufactured. Great design and I thoroughly enjoy the amount of decision-making generated by the mechanic. Each new building consumes a "building slot".

This game is sort of a combo: tower defense and city building are the main mechanic. But the game also adds a god spell-casting mechanism, which allows casting fireballs, earthquakes, holy golems, healing aura, resurrect the ghost, and a few others, all with varying essence costs, which is slowly building up over time according to how happy villagers are.

Most importantly, there is a "grab anything" spell that allows grabbing enemies, friends, resources -- just not buildings. You can use it to move enemies away if they are causing too much trouble, or saving your villagers before certain death, or collecting resources your villagers aren't collecting fast enough. Each time you use it it burns essence depending on how long you grab something. This has the side-effect of making game-pause disallow touching the board in any way (pause also won't let you use the building-selection menus, but the dev claims he will change this eventually). Not being able to change a paused board I find annoying, especially when it's only reason is to support a strange game-play mechanism. The game develops an arcade-like feel (i.e. frantically moving things around), when it's supposed to be a city-builder. It's odd.  [Most city builders involve dropping "blueprints" that workers eventually build the buidings on top of - but this is the first city builder I have seen that won't let you pause and place as many blueprints as you like - you have to unpause the game to do that.]

Another odd mechanism is that the global map (where you choose the submap the village will be placed in) can have units (enemy or ally) in "limbo", and they can be portalled out of a map or back in as you like. I scratch my head at why this was put in - but there it is.


But wait! There's more! There are also 2 other mini-games: - collect the essence and - find the friend or foe. 

Collect The Essence

Collect the essence involves moving your mouse around essence that results from enemy deaths or other triggers that have it free-floating in the atmosphere. The way the essence follows bezier curves is fun to watch and it's a bit relaxing break from the rest of the game.

Find The Friend Or Foe

The other minigame "find the friend or foe" involves hovering the mouse close enough to ground units to see whether they are enemies or friends (your own villagers or nomads). If you don't have your mouse close enough, you can't see what they are. This I think was a really bad UI choice for the sake of creating a mini-game. I find it purely annoying. Your mileage may vary.


Conclusion

The game involves several mini-games, some add and some detract from the core gameplay, which is castle (or city) building. Because this is still early access, who knows? But I feel I've already gotten my money's worth purely for the mechanisms I like, and it's very easy to keep playing this until the late hours of the night. For that reason alone, it's worth a buy.

31027723.review:
[h1]OVERVIEW[/h1]
Note: Rise to Ruins is currently in Early Access. The version reviewed was InDev25d.

Rise to Ruins is a village simulator with some god game elements, from indie developer Raymond Doerr. It was previously titled Retro-Pixel Castles.

In Rise to Ruins, you're given a group of settlers with whom you have to found a village and survive for as long as possible. Like most games of this type, there's no real end goal -- or at least none that I'm aware of -- instead you tend to play until your village is wiped out (or nearly so) and then you start again and try to do better next time. The game includes seasonal climate changes and a day/night cycle, both of which present further complications and challenges, but which are great additions to the game.

[h1]Graphics[/h1]
The game is played from a top-down overhead view, with characters (people and monsters) drawn from a three-quarter perspective to give them a bit more personality. You can adjust the zoom from a functional-but-not-quite-far-enough minimum, allowing you to see a fair bit of the surrounding area, up to a chunky-pixel maximum, where a single villager takes up a fair portion of the screen. At minimum zoom the game looks quite nice, with map tiles being well drawn, and characters looking like colourful ants. At maximum zoom the characters look a bit too blocky for my liking.

There are no real graphics detail settings, though there are particle and shadow settings, and the obligatory windowed/full-screen options. (ProTip: Don't play in full screen; it's very buggy.) It's not a graphics-heavy game by any means, but it chugs along nicely even with a hundred or so villagers all going about their business.

[h1]Sound[/h1]
Music has a nice fantasy/mediaeval theme that suits the game well in my opinion. Sound effects are functional, but nothing special.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
Rise to Ruins begins with an overhead map of the game's continent, from which you select a region in which you want to settle your first village. These locations differ in available resources and, I think, climate, so choose carefully. (You can found multiple villages in different regions, but you only have a limited pool of villagers, shared between them all.)

After you've chosen a region the game takes you to the region map, from which you'll play the game proper. There's no real tutorial at the moment, but the game gives you some help in the form of pop-up tips. These are a bit lacking, though. For example, I had no food growth and no food, but nothing in any of the tips told me I should build anything until it was too late, and even then I didn't know the best place to build it. An in-game tutorial would really help; the youtube tutorial video notwithstanding. Still, although you should be able to work out the very basics pretty easily, it's a steep learning curve when things go wrong and you don't know why. The Steam Discussions are a useful resource.

Anyway, you choose a section of promising looking land -- water, rocks, trees, and wild food, if you can find it, are all good -- and build a camp. That then lets you build other buildings, too, and before long you're harvesting resources and growing your camp into a little village community.

As is common to many god games, you don't have any direct control over your people; you can assign them to tasks -- builder is the only one available to begin with, but as you build more buildings, more jobs become available -- and that's about it. To harvest resources you select and highlight them on the map, and your people are supposed to harvest as many as they need, and no more.

You very quickly need to build up some basic infrastructure, including housing, food growth, water processing, and some rudimentary defences, the latter being required because you never know when a wandering monster might wander into your village and start attacking your people. Combat seems to be stacked against you, too; you don't have any really good 'troops' of your own, and the tower-defence style of defence doesn't quite seem to work: monsters bash through walls rather than being funnelled to your 'kill zone', and it's sometimes hard to even notice them in the first place, with no ability to automatically focus on important events.

You also have a small collection of god powers, which you can use by spending your collected essence: another resource, but one that's harvested by you rather than your people. I was a little disappointed in these, as I'd been hoping for a bit more range and depth to them, but what's there is useful and well thought out. I guess it would be fair to say they're more like Populous than Populous II.

Rise to Ruins has been in Early Access for about two-and-a-half years, so you'd be forgiven for worrying that it had been abandoned. It definitely hasn't, though: the developer releases regular updates and is active in the Steam Community for the game. As you'd expect from an EA title, though, Rise to Ruins does have some bugs. My first hour with the game consisted of about 15 minutes of playtime, followed by 45 minutes of trying to recover from a crash. The game just wouldn't restart and instead sat there spinning Windows' blue wheel of doom until I killed it. I eventually manually edited the settings and turned off full-screen mode and after that it worked again.

You'll encounter minor issues, too. Even with many idle people I found that building would often stop due to no resources being available, so the automatic resource harvesting seems to need a bit of adjustment. The UI is a bit wonky and controls aren't what I would choose, either, but they're functional, and the developer has stated that he reworks the UI every now and then, so what's here now may not be here forever. There's a big message reminding you to press the middle mouse button to cancel whenever you're in the middle of an action, such as designating resources or using god powers; it's lucky it's there, since middle mouse button to cancel is not intuitive at all.

[h1]PROS AND CONS[/h1]
Pros:
+ Detailed and in-depth simulation; there's a lot to learn
+ Different game modes from casual and explorative (sandbox) to VERY challenging (survival)
+ Solid design with a dedicated developer
+ Nice music, nice graphics at lower zoom levels

Cons:
- No proper tutorial, making for a very steep learning curve
- Some bad bugs, especially in full screen
- Some awkward controls
- Combat isn't that great

[h1]CONCLUSION[/h1]
I've only just begun to learn some of Rise to Ruin's intricacies, but I can see there's a lot here. It still has plenty of rough edges, but the developer releases frequent updates and is always responding to comments.

If you have the time to invest in it, I expect you'll find Rise to Ruins very rewarding.

30905957.review:
Spielmechanik: 9/10 Punkten
Grafik: 10/10 Punkten
Sound: 8/10 Punkten
Gameplay: 9/10 Punkten
Support/Zukunft: 9/10 Punkten

Kurzfazit: Für den geringen Preis von unter 10 Euro ist es ein absolutes muss! 


Lange Version:

Ich habe mir das Spiel mit der Erwartung gekauft, dass es sich um eine Aufbau-Dorfsimulation mit Monstern handelt. Die Mischung aus Aufbaustrategie, Dorfsimulation (mit Survivalelementen) und Tower-Defence hat mich positiv überrascht. Es ist sehr gut aufeinander abgestimmt und was mir sehr wichtig ist, keiner der Aspekte dominiert. Diese Mischung macht das Spiel einzigartig.

Spielmechanik:
Bei Early Accress (kurz: EA) Spielen bin ich bei dieser Wertung sehr zurückhaltend. Normalerweise funktioniert dies oder jenes noch nicht so gut, so dass es eigentlich Punktabzüge geben müsste. Nicht bei Rise to Ruins, denn auch wenn es sich um ein EA Spiel handelt, so haben alle Spielmechaniken, Buttons und Prinzipien funktioniert. Einzig die Steuerung und Menu-Anordnung müsste noch einmal etwas verbessert werden. 

Grafik: 
Schaut euch selbst die wunderschönen Bilder an. Die Grafik wird mit sehr schönen Animationen und Effekten untermalen. Das Gesamtbild ist stimmig und die Welt wird sehr schön dargestellt. Dies ist vor allem an so kleinen aber wichtigen Details wie, dass wenn es regnet der Regen auf von den Dächern fällt, bzw sich Pfüzten bilden, zu merken.

Sound:
Der Sound ist an sich stimmig, aber ich finde hier ginge noch mehr. Aber es ist ein Beschweren auf hohem Niveau. Ähnlich wie bei der Grafik wurde hier teilweise sehr an den Details gefeilt. Bspw. wenn es Blitzt ist es auch nach jeweiliger Kameraposition dort der Ton zu hören/bzw. lauter zu hören. Gegenden wie Wälder, Wiesen oder Gebirge haben leider kein eigene Sounds.

Gameplay:
Das wichtigste Vorweg: Man muss sich daran gewöhnen, dass man verliert. Egal wie gut ich bin, irgendwann werden die Monster zu viele und/oder zu stark. Aber genau hier liegt die Stärke des Spiels. Man verbessert sich mit jedem Durchgang ein wenig, so dass man noch einen Tag länger überlebt. Und dabei ist das Spiel durchaus sehr fair! 

Einziger wirklicher Kritikpunkt am Gameplay ist das "Limbosystem". Bei Beginn des Spiels holt man sich seine Einwohner und ersten Ressourcen aus dem "Limbo". Man kann als Spieler Ressourcen und Einwohner auch wieder in den "Limbo" schicken, kostet aber Einfluss. Man kann aber auch Ressourcen und Einwohner während des Spiels aus dem "Limbo" holen. Bei einem weiteren Durchgang in der Welt, nimmt man die verbleibenden Ressourcen und Einwohner des "Limbo". Wenn es zu wenige sind kann man keine neue Siedlung gründen und muss die Welt "reseten".
Mir persönlich würde es besser gefallen, wenn man jedes mal mit exakt dem selben Ressourcen und Einwohnern anfangen würde, statt sich für die kommende male evtl. immer stärker zu machen.

Support/Zukunft:
Es wird aktiv am Spiel entwickelt und die Updates kommen regelmäßig. Kritik und Ideen werden aufgenommen, genauso wie Bugs gefixt. Mit dem letzten großen Update kam auch noch ein weiteres großes Feature in das Spiel. 
Ich sehe bei diesem Spiel, wenn der Entwickler so dran bleibt, eine rosige Zukunft mit steigenden Verkaufszahlen.


Fazit: 
Ich finde den Preis für dieses sehr spaßige, herausfordernde aber/und auch süchtig machende Spiel mehr als angemessen. Ich kann jedem Freund vom Wuselfaktor (Siedler), Dortsimulationen (Banished) und Aufbaustrategie nur empfehlen. 
Alle anderen sollten es sich zumindest mal anschauen, denn dieses Spiel ist einzigartig und das sollte gewürdigt werden.  :)

Pros:

-Love the pixel art style of the game

-Tower defense aspects set it apart a bit from other Dwarf Fortress-likes, combat is an extremely core part of the game and that's not a bad thing at all.

-Totally reasonable price. I got it on sale for $5, but even the default price of $10 is reasonable. I bought this less than a week ago as of this review and I already have over 24 hours put into it. The dev is also extremely active so I'm confident in the game's future.

-Plenty of content already - a lot of resources, items, and buildings to create.


Cons:

-Slow pace. The dev has already expressed he has no plans to include a 2x/3x speed option like in games such as Banished or RimWorld, however he will be including a Haste spell to speed your workers up. From what I can tell, this spell will really only be truly useful in the very first 2 or 3 days, because after that you will want to save your mana to blow up enemy spawns. So I don't think that the Haste spell will really solve much. The dev has stated higher speeds would be unnecessary because of the pace of the game, but I find myself with tons of downtime at every stage of the game. If it is a problem of implementation, I can understand, but I see no reason why an optional 2x or 3x speed button shouldn't be added.

-Difficulty does not continue to scale. Now that I've done a few runs and I have a strategy for early-mid game, I'm completely ironclad and unstoppable by around day 11. More enemies will probably need to be added (remember you can always do resizes/recolors of existing sprites, nobody gets too upset about that as long as it's not rampant) that can add to more of a late game challenge.

-Defense is pretty easy. All you need to do is make a large perimeter for your base and include a single choke point. Because of the enemy AI, they will walk across the entire map just to get to that choke point. I would recommend adding a certain distance threshold for enemies so that if they have to walk a certain distance to get around a wall, they will instead attack the nearest wall. This will force players to maintain multiple points of defense instead of one easily defended chokepoint.


Misc suggestions:

Quarries like in Banished - on rock floor areas, maybe you could add a building that allows villagers to mine a set amount of rock and iron from a 10x10 spot or however large you'd deem it. My reasoning for this is that I often run out of stone toward the end of the second year, and this would add another way of getting some. It's basically like they're hollowing out that part of the ground.

Diagonal roads - just make it so that when roads are connected to another road by only the corner you use a particular diagonal-road sprite. This is for both aesthetic reasons and because diagonal roads are obviously useful given by their automatic creation by the NPCs' pathing.

Alternative food sources - domesticated animals, fish.

Towers that induce status effects (slow, bleed, decrease armor, etc)

Difficult games fall into two catagories: Those that are challenging, and those that are frustrating.  This game, alas, falls into the later category.  

My main issues:
1.  There is no good way to control overheating in summer.  Especially when the 1200hp Zombie is fighting them all in the middle of the day.  They stand and fight and die of heat exhaustion.  
2.  The monster difficulty seems to grow exponentially.  On day 3, it's not uncommon for 700 to 800 hp monsters to waltz through my defences.  By day 5, they're close to 1500 hp.  I've never made it past that point, so I can only guess how vastly overpowered they become.
3.  The inability to rotate buildings.  When most buildings are rectangles, it helps to compact your base.
4.  The monsters just break through the walls, rather than going through the killing maze.  It's impossible to concentrate enough fire when they come through whatever wall is inconvenient to them.
5.  What it boils down to is a tower defence game with a focus on the infrastructure behind the towers.  It's not what I was expecting from a village simulator.  I'm not a big fan of tower defence games to begin with, so this was a rather sad realization.
6.  There are no guards or soldiers.  You get golems who can't stand a chance against anything but a slime.  It would be nice to have soldiers who could sortie out and soften up the monsters.

EDIT:
I am changing my review to positive.  The developer is prompt and courteous, and there seems to be a lot of changes in the works.  I kind of forgot the game is in alpha still because of how well it looks and, aside from the frustrations mentioned above, works.  

I suppose, deep down, I'm afraid of getting burned by another Towns.  Thankfully, I don't think that's a concern here.  I look forward to the continued development of what portends to be a great time waster.
