The sole developer, Raymond Doerr, is offering up a first class Early Access experience. He seems to be astoundingly active, quickly answering messages on twitter, Steam and the dedicated official game site, which is itself well maintained with an artful attention to detail. 

Updates come thick and fast, with a casual little suggestion of mine turning up in a patch a day later. Very gratifying! You can really see how determined he is to make this something great, accounting for every piece of feedback. So I'm fully reassured that, even though it's almost two year's since the successful Kickstarter, Retro-Pixel Castles will eventually reach a proper, full release, however long is need to make it a really great gaming experience.

As of the current version, inDev22e, I'd say that the game alone is only just about worth it's price tag. There are a couple of nights worth of obsessive play in there, building out your village and defense setup, provided you have a modicum of patience to get into it. After failing initially, I personally watched the handily linked 'tutorial' video, to get the gist of a few basics. The in-game tips were very helpful too. But having figured out how to survive the initial onslaught, the excitement does trail off... The transition to starting a new village map is currently a little rough and without any campaign mechanism in place yet there's no particular motivation to go through the motions more than a couple times.

However, it looks like the game's meta is due to change with the upcoming monthly major update and there are a lot of promising additions lined up. Really looking forwards to the future of this project. :-)

Bear in mind that while this game is the same genre as Rimworld, it's pretty distinct from it - it's more like supervising a colony of ants, with no capacity or need to micromanage each little person. I feel the villager AI works pretty well, but it's best not to worry too much about the fine detail, just plan out your build strategy and keep an eye on those monsters. Also, there's a significant (and hopefully growing) tower defense aspect to the play, with it being possible to build little mazes for enemies to path through while getting shot. Quite a novel marriage of two of my favorite, most addictive game genres!

Also be warned that the game can run a little choppily under certain circumstances, but is getting better optimized with each update and refinements are also due that should help avoid overly demanding conditions. Likewise I experienced a couple of crashes initially, but the frequent auto-save meant I never lost any progress and I've been unable to replicate the problem after recent updates. Continuous improvement.

25980465.review:
[h1]Introduction[/h1]
Retro-Pixel Castles: The Godlike Village Simulator is developed by Raymond Doerr and published by SixtyGig Games. While still in Early Access, it shows promise and it is by no means a small feat, given the fact that this title is the dev team’s first Steam project.
 
[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
Even though there’s not one playthrough similar to another, Retro-Pixel Castles does offer the necessary tools and assets needed for both the survival as well as thriving of the miniaturized society being simulated in our case. If there’s one good thing that comes out of such random scenarios, is that boredom has a hard time setting in provided you are familiar with the god game formula. It’s definitely harder than economic simulators/city builders that are more abundent on Steam. You have to constantly keep an eye on your villagers and protect them from natural hazards and foes, while also having a clear expansion pattern as the resources on the maps do encourage some planning ahead. The game’s tutorial felt a bit thin on content and tips, but there’s still room for improvement. While it may seem rather difficult for beginners, once you know how to prioritize your building projects and manage the initial small population, things become much easier.
 
The audio-visual department is the one that might require some more tinkering from the developer’s side. Music and soud effects seem quite repetitive while the fonts have a slight resolution problem. Zooming in or out would be nice touches as the pixelated graphics don’t bother me at all. In such a game which features enough gameplay complexity as it is, the eye candy can be safely overlooked.

EDIT: Trading Cards have been added to this game.
 
[h1]Pros[/h1]
+ Steam Trading Cards
+ Randomly generated assets
+ Freedom of choice with an open-ended storyline

[h1]Cons[/h1]
- No Achievements
- Still in Early Access
- Sounds are repetitive

[h1]Result / Final thoughts[/h1]
It is truly unfortunate that we have such a limited selection of god games on the Steam Store, but we must make do with what can be found already as well as the newly released ones. Retro-Pixel Castles is just such a title, both promising and with a charm of its own. More than enough to stand out and not be considered just a shout-out to an often neglected genre.

Fun game if you enjoy the base building type of games.  (I do so I loved this game.)  

For the most part, the gameplay and buildings are fairly straightforward.  There's definitely a learning curve to this game, though.  You will most likely have to start over at least a couple times. However, once you figure out your strategy and build a solid defence, the only struggle may be to have enough food during the winter.

I got it on sale for about $5 which is already well worth the price even without the fact that it will be updated.  My personal check for games is that it's, at least, satisfactory if it provides enough fun game play for one hour for every dollar it cost.  (So 3 hours/dollar so far is pretty good.)

Quick tips if you want them:
-Focus on a good defense ASAP. There's always room for improvement. Like dont even worry about having all the necessary housing.  You start in spring so the villagers can go a few nights outside.  Just build a good wall and defense towers (and ammo supply) ,  And use natural barriers to your adventure (forests and mountains.)

-Don't spready yourself thin, too fast.  You start off with only so many people.  If you start building and employing all the different manufacturing and refining buildings, Your people will be spread thin among all them and it'll take forever to get more important things dones.

-Edges to waters aren't as defensive as you think.  If you build a wall ending perpendicular to a body of water, monsters can still swim around the edge (Depending on what the quickest path is.)

-Destroy spawners asap.  Use the Fireball power on any spawners that pop up (red squares on minimap).  You don't need to destroy them completely.  If you hit them, they'll slowly burn until they're destroyed (unless it starts to rain.)

25845720.review:
So I picked up RPC a couple of days ago, having kept an eye on it several years back on TIGSource, and I have to say that this game is one of the best I've played in a long long time. Combining my two favourite genres, TD and RTS with a pinch of Roller Coaster Tycoon, I have so far had an absolute blast. 

The game starts you on an island world map with the choice of your settling point - You can even go in and look at the maps first before setting up. Once you do that, you've got to balance the livelihoods of your population whilst being besieged by armies of monsters. You begin by gathering the basics - Food and Wood, but over time becoming accustomed with a diverse collection of structures and materials. Production lines form, your civilisation grows, squeezing in between valleys and digging into the safety of bedrock, rather than risking expanding outwards. In turn, beyond your bastions, holes open in the ground in increasing number as more enemies spill onto the map, slowly colouring the minimap red. 

The gameplay remains perfectly in flow with a fluctuating day/night cycle and on top of which 4 seasons that constantly mix up gameplay with various weather and effects on your settlement. You really have to stock up for winter (And the first year I massively over prepared, but better safe than sorry!) HINT - MAKE AS MANY FARMS AS YOU CAN - 28 farmers was a sustainable number for me (Whilst enriching wild food collections at the same time!).

Most tower defences suffer from the same issue over time that they become tedious as you perfect your strategy. The twist that has hooked me for RPC is you have the option to send units to "limbo", essentially a menu screen where you can dish out your settlers to a variety of different lands on the map. I spent an hour just surveying the various maps and looking for potential choke points, weighing up the different collections of resources in each area, hesitant to send my villagers to certain doom after such a firm foothold on my first settlement.

To add to this, I found myself grappling with the dilemmas of logging regulation (Do I flatten the forest to supplement my bow towers with arrows, but deal with the long grow back time and pathways destroying the treeline opened up) and I found myself picking single people to inhabit my future settlement to avoid breaking up my many many married couples (170 villagers so far!) 

Another fantastic mechanic is the line of sight for defences - Punishing players who box themselves in by preventing them from expanding beyond their walls. There were many times where I'd tear down a couple of the inner walls to frantically assemble some lines of trenches further forwards whilst fighting off hordes of monsters then patch my defences back up before nightfall. It puts a lot more risk in expansion and forces you to avoid greediness.

The game has such depth that I've sunk over half a day into the Retro Pixel Castles over the weekend. 

It's just such a good game! I can't put it any simpler than that, haven't felt so transfixed about a strategy game since I discovered Age of Empires 2. 

Admittedly, the lack of a built in tutorial is something that could do with addressing, but obviously with Early Access I'm sure it's something that'll come about in time. The video that was linked in the game did provide me with enough information to get started with, so thank you for providing that. Having said this, discovering the functions of the game over time has been quite satisfying in itself - I'm still unlocking the mysteries of essence!

It's a bit of a far fetched request (Especially with the number of units and stuff going on at once, but I would adore a co-op mode for this. 

Either way, amazing work, and I look forward to any approaching updates for the project.

Early Access, 9,99€ -> 4,99€  (-50%). 17.5h jugadas.

Personalmente, la compra me ha salido rentable.

 
A día de hoy, 1 de octubre del 2016, es un juego de gráficos "sencillos pero simpáticos", cosa que no creo que cambie demasiado, cuya jugabilidad me ha querido recordar a un mestizaje del Dwarf Fortress y el Black & White.

Se plantea como un juego en el que tienes que hacer que un pueblo y sus gentes duren el máximo tiempo posible, antes de que hordas de monstruos se los lleve por delante. Para ello, tienes que sobrevivir en un continente con varios terrenos en los que "desplegar" tu centro de la aldea, elegir dentro de esa zona (mapa ya de juego) el lugar más apropiado para asentarte, expandirte y crecer.

Necesitas explotar 4 recursos: alimentos, madera, piedra y cristal, y llegado el momento, refinarlos. A base de refinar obtendrás nuevos recursos con los que crear mejores edificios y defensas.

El primer año de supervivencia vendría a ser un tutorial, o al menos es cuando te llegan los consejos. Cada año consta de las cuatro estaciones y cada estación de un puñao de días. Con la llegada de la noche los monstruos se activan más de lo debido, y van a tratar de arrasar la aldea.

------------

He necesitado 3 intentos antes de sacar un juego decente. El primero no tenía idea de nada y me dediqué a hacer probatinas (desactivados los consejos, estaba más perdido que un pulpo en un garaje), el segundo ya había descubierto algunas cosas, y con los consejos activados, fue algo mejor, por lo que pasé directamente al tercero, en el cual me encuentro actualmente. Primavera del tercer año, me encuentro cómodo con mi zona y ya me he expandido prácticamente por un tercio del mapa.

De los 32 aldeanos que contaba al principio, ahora son cerca de 140. En el primer año me atrincheré apoyándome del entorno y en el segundo comencé lentamente la expansión. A principios del tercero, voy holgado de recursos y alimentos, quedando los monstruos relegados a poco más que una anécdota fronteriza. Voy trabajando en etapas de expansión por el día, ganando terreno y construyendo defensas, asentando de forma sólida la posición antes de continuar con la ampliación.

Dudo mucho que la máquina sea capaz de "echarme" de la zona, estoy cómodo y la siento mía, por lo que en cuanto la tenga dominada (de aquí al 5to o 6to año, supongo), iniciaré una nueva aldea en el continente, en alguna de las zonas colindantes (entiéndase, otro mapa).

----------------------

Hay un par de cosas que no me cuadran de la versión actual:
- Cullis gate. Hay varias en la zona y sirven para traer y meter cosas del Limbo. (El Limbo es el "Almacén", si todo lo que metas ahí lo puedes sacar en otra tierra; teorizo, aún no he iniciado otra tierra, pero juraría que está para eso). Cosa que no tiene mucho sentido, ya que siendo Dios, que lo somos, tenemos un poder en el que llevar y traer cosas del Limbo.
 * Lo curioso, es que puedes crear una Cullis Gate de cosecha propia. No sé para qué si ya hay varias en el mapa y, mantengo, puedo sacarlos por omnipotencia del Limbo a la fuerza. xD

-Monstruos actuales: Slim (algunos al ¿matarlos? sueltan varios slims más), Tío sin cabeza, Tío quemao, Zombi, Espectro, y... ya, creo que ya. Van variando de nivel entre 1 y... 16 a día de hoy, y el aldeano más avezado rondará el 14. Estaría muy bien algún monstruo aéreo o subterráneo que pudiese incordiar tras las líneas de defensa. En plan arpías, topo-sierpes o alguna cosa por el estilo.
 * Los aldeanos pueden tener miedo de los monstruos. Vigila que no corran en la dirección equivocada.
 * Los Espectros de N13-16... como lleguen al cuerpo a cuerpo... cuidao.
 * Los Tíos quemaos, que van ardiendo más bien, son un peligro importante para los aldeanos, te los ponen a arder y cómo te descuides palman al poco rato del combate.
 * Aparecen de forma aleatoria estructuras de los monstruos, destrúyelas con presteza o prepara la vaselina.

-------------

Resumiendo, me he gastado 5€ en este juego en Early Acces y le he dedicado 17.5h, así que haga lo que haga el creador a mí ya me ha salido rentable. El juego en la fase actual puede dar para más aunque ya me he cansao un poco, aunque también diré que no soy especialmente constante con los juegos, la verdad.

Lo recomiendo, sí, por supuesto. Además el creador sigue trabajando y seguirá trabajando en él una vez el juego esté completo. Y lo más importante, no habrá *u*os DLC's. 

Chapó. GG, WP. 

Toma mi dinero, te lo mereces. 

Hasta ahora ha sido una experiencia más que decente. = )

Early Access Review:

It took me a couple sittings before the game finally reeled me in, but boy has it given me that "one more turn" feel like Civ or Empire Earth. tl;dr at the bottom.

So what is Retro-Pixel Castles?

Right now it's basically a sandbox survival village building / god simulation game. As it's Early Access the content is currently limited, but there is enough to get a good idea of how great this game could be should it continue to go the direction it is currently being developed.

What do you do?

You can build a village, collect resources, expand your population, defend your land from monsters that attack at night, and then expand your control beyond the current map and export units/resources to "Limbo" where you can access them on other maps as part of the World Map system.

What can't you do (yet)?

Currently there are no animals, as noted by the dev. Building diversity is also very limited; you can see one or two variations of defensive buildings that use each resource type, there is essentially only one gathering building for each type of resource (wood, stone, and crystal), only one resource "refining" building for each type of resource, inventory management is a bit awkward--no ability to to prioritize what resources get stored in large storage buildings. Also magic buildings are limited to a portal to Limbo, an essence collecter (used to power magic defense structures), and a crystal motivator (regenerates your natural crystal deposits so they can be harvested sooner.), and a few defensive buildings.

There is also currently only one playable race/faction. I would love to see different races / tribes that have alternate methods of collecting resources and different technologies/structures. As someone who grew up with Warcraft 2 and 3, I really fell in love with the base building. (I loved how the Undead didn't have to travel to collect gold, and how the Night Elves could collect wood without destroying trees, thus allowing forests to exist as walls where-as the Humans/Orcs eventually destroy every resource in their path to find each other.)

Music is simple and satisfying, but I think it could use more variety as with most of the rest of the game.

I hope the dev keeps on improving this game because I'm hooked, I want to see more but I'm afraid even when I expand to my second base there won't be anything but new terrain to see.

tl;dr:

This game is a fun mix of Dwarf Fortress and Warcraft 2/3. The graphics are colorful and bright. You can build a maze of walls for the monsters to run through turning it in to a real survival tower defense. I recommend it to anyone who likes retro village building.

I know that this is Early Acces, but the game is in desperate need of content.
All there is right now is three different resources, with their respective extractors and refinements, houses and towers. To be a village sim you might need a little more than that, honestly.

You are constantly attacked by monsters, day and night, without breaks. You can't tell your villagers to defend, you can only build towers (that are inadequate for the amount of monsters you receive), and hope for some villager to try and defend and not die. Because if they die, the only way to have another villager is to give free time (aka, stop building your village defenses) to your workers and wait a loooong time before a new one is born, while in the mean time you have less defenses and even more monsters.

The AI is very lackluster: building two or more buildings at a time really confuse builders, with the end result of having both of them unfinished for minutes. Gathering resource is dumb too, with villagers going for random sources instead of the nearest ones. Attacking enemies seems random too, with villagers attacking once, then starting to flee, then attacking again, then fleeing in the middle of other enemies, then dying.

On the art side of things: the graphics and UI are gorgeous. The sound track is quite good, although it isn't contextual: you can have an happy and reassuring track while the village is getting slaughtered. Particle effects are really cool and really add a lot to the presentation of the game.

For now I absolutely cannot recommend this game in the current state. I hope new content and new mechanics will be added to the game and the AI refined, so that this game will actually be about managing your village, not an endless cycle of building and rebuilding towers.

23237833.review:
This game is very well made. Even though it´s still in development, it looks very promising.

It´s a combination of a management game and a godgame, where you have to build, maintain and protect your own village(s). And those two genres have been merged together very well in this game.

I recently bought it as I saw it in the store and it caught my attention. It looked like a simple management game, indie style. I have played Banished before, and it looks a bit like it, but this game has it's own characteristics as well. You have an "influence bar", which acts as a mana bar. With this influence, you can cast godly spells to improve land, fireball land/enemies/enemy buildings and much more.

The game itself is very simple: You start with a global map with a couple of locations where you can start your first village. When you've chosen your location, you can start building! But you have to be fast. Just like other games, the night is very dangerous. The first night will remail calm, but the second night things go down... quickly.

The game has a season mechanic. You start in the spring, the easiest of all 4 seasons as food grows the quickest in this season. You have to stockpile food to make sure you can get through the summer, where food growth is significantly slower. The autumn is the second best season, where you can recover from the summer. Though not optimal, it's still good enough to re-establish your food stockpile, as the next season is the harshest: winter. Food growth is almost at a halt, so you better have some food stored. However, with your godly abilities you can grab food from over the map and drop it in the village, to make sure you'll get through winter... if you even get there.

Because when playing the regular game, survival mode, so-called "graveyards" and "slime spawns" spawn quite often, spawning many enemies. Eventually a lot of the map is covered with these graveyards and when the night comes, they can assault your village. If you haven't prepared your defences before that happens, it's pretty much over (RIP me :( ).

But if you want to take it easy, there is also a peaceful mode, where almost no enemies spawn. It's a good way to learn the mechanics, as it's way more forgiving if you are a bit slow. If you don't know how to play the game at first, at the main menu there's a button which redirects you to a youtube video, explaining some of the basic mechanics of the game. It's quite helpful. You'll get tips on how to make your defences as good as possible and how different defensive towers work.

It has some performence issues (at least for me) when autosaving, where your screen freezes for the duration. It isn't that bad, its usually for less than a second. There isn't however a way to decrease graphics so you have to play with a lot of particles all the time. And it's a lot, because there has been a lot of attention to details, which I absolutely love.

The soundtrack is cute and athmospheric. It makes this game even more cute than it already is. That, which the sometimes corky and sometimes sarcastic pop-ups when you lose a villager or at the splashart of the main menu, makes it a very cute product over all.

I'd give this an 8/10. It's very cute, it shows potential. However, it is a bit repetitive as you cannot develop a lot with for example a tech-tree or something. It's more like when you can process your wood and stone, you can basically build everything, which makes it somewhat less exciting rather quick. Yet it's a good game to kill some time with. You'll fall in love with the cuteness!

The game itself is very challenging on its own terms, in a way that inspires you to continue learning and strategizing despite many failed attempts. The gameplay is very fluid (though the framerate sometimes isn't) and is structured very intuitively.

+Love the interactive Main menu
+The visuals of the game are so crisp and well designed, but I wish you could zoom out a little more, and zooming in as much as is available just hurts my eyes.

+The map editor is excellent.

22056366.review:
Retro-Pixel Castles is an interesting game that seems to show great promise.

How would I describe the game? I guess I would say that it's something of a god-sim mixed with a city-building sim. Nothing too outside the box, generally speaking.

What else can I really say? My little men and women run about the world, mating and harvesting and mating some more (and stopping to chat all the damn time), and I continue to direct them to build stone walls, fire towers, and refining facilities. There's not much more to it at this point. However, that's due to the fact that the game is still in early access rather than any lack of vision on the part of the developers. I can see that there is a lot of room to grow in Retro-Pixel Castles and I have high hopes that the devs will continue to utilize that space.

The tutorials cover most everything you will need to know (not everything, of course, but they're tutorials - not strategy guides. I feel like there should be some information left to the player to discover). It's not difficult to figure out how to get a thriving community up and running once you understand the basic build order.

I guess that would be one of my main complaints about the game (and there aren't too many complaints I could actually list - see the end of the review for my short list): once you understand the basic build order of the game there isn't very much in the way of challenge with attaining a thriving community. It seems like the game is, so far, simple and easy. This can be changed further on in development, and I feel like with the addition of more content the challenge rating should rise decently.

Since pro/con lists seem to be all the rage in reviews, I will use one now. This list is not exhaustive.

Pros:
+Easy to learn mechanics
+Enjoyable and open-ended simulation
+Pleasing graphical elements
+Entertaining gameplay

Cons:
-Soundtrack gets repetitive
-It can be a bit of a hassle figuring out which unit is your villager and which is the monster in a large melee
-Small amount of content at this point
-Lack of effective late-game purpose (once I've built all the buildings and made my havens safe for my townsfolk there isn't any reason to continue except to raise a large population in order to populate more areas of the map)

I want to make a note that I feel like all of the cons so listed are easily fixed and I have a good feeling that the devs are either currently working towards those goals or will soon begin to do so.

I won't waste any time attempting to offer my thoughts as to how to fix said cons - this is simply a review.

Anyway, without going on too long (too late) I would have to say this: if you're a fan of god sims or city building sims then you should definitely keep an eye on this game. With a few more updates I think it could easily become a mainstay of your gaming repertoire. With a full complement of content I feel that Retro-Pixel Castles could be something great.

[b]Pros:[/b]

- Graphics: This is a more personally pro for me, but I love the graphics on this game. The retro style is easy on the eyes and it's not hard to differentiate various things. That being said, if you expect crazy graphics from this game, this ain't the game for you

- Controls: The controls are very easy to learn and get used to. Granted, I would like more hotkeys for various buildings/spells but I'm sure that they'll be implemented later on. Nonetheless, the controls are easy to learn and master

- UI: The information that you need are so easily presented/accessible that you can see whatever you want either immediately or with a few clicks

[b]Cons:[/b]

- Long Term Playability: The only real problem that I have with RPC is the lack of content in the late game. Once you're able to get to the late game harvesting buildings, there's really nothing else to do. However, I see this as a short term problem as this game is early access and from what I can gather from the dev's plans, this issue may be resolved

- Difficulty: Similar to the problem above, once you get to the late game there really isn't anything that can threaten you. Is it impossible to fail, no. In fact, if there is a huge wave of monsters, you can and will fail through either poor management of spells or poor AI. However, as stated before this is mostly short term as this is early access and could be fixed through variety or increase in difficulty


[b]Overall[/b]: RPC is a great game, its retro style graphics and simplistic menus can lead towards hours of enjoyable gameplay. However, the lack of late game buildings/progression as well as the lack of difficulty past the initial phase of gameplay does bring the game down a lot. There has been quite some times where I would be bored since there was no new goal for me to reach or no new threat for me to fear. 現在、開発のどの段階かは分からないが、投稿時点ではまだプレイをオススメできる状態ではない。
将来は分からないが、現時点での良い点と悪い点を列挙しておく。


良い点

・音楽が良い。PVだけでなく、ゲーム中の音楽もゴッドゲームの雰囲気が良く出ている。

悪い点

・敵の強さが鬼畜すぎて、村作りゲーであるという事をしばしば忘れる。

敵やAIが調整されて、作れる施設が増えれば超オススメになるポテンシャルを秘めているが、現時点ではオススメできない。
今できるのは10日目辺りからやってくる凶悪なモンスター群からどうやって身を守るかという、血の滲む村民生き残りレースだけである。

リソースや住人はスペルで別のマップに移動できるので、高レベルの住人を移動させたりすれば、生き延びられる日数を増やせない事もない。

いずれにせよあれこれ工夫しないと長く遊べないのは確か。

プレイヤーはLIMBO(辺獄)とかいう天国と地獄の中間っぽいところから地上へ指示し、魔法を通じ資源や住民を投下/回収して管理する。

住民の増殖は男女結婚して子供を産むのみで、非常～～にペースが遅く全力で住民の保護をしないと敵の増加に対応不能となる。
ちゃんと見回りをして危なくなった住民はプレイヤーのテレポート魔法で救助してあげよう。

住民は建物ごとに担当者を割り当てないとニートしてる上に「ちょっとあそぼうぜ！」して社会人の手を止めてしまうので仕事の割り振りバランスが重要。しかし会話がないと住民は運命の相手が見つからず結婚できないのでブラックLIMBOに未来はない。
なお黄色い子は職業割り振り不能な永遠の警備員(HERO)なので数も少ないうえに勇敢なので暖かい目で(緊急回復的な意味で)見てあげてください。

魔法については「プレイヤーの魔法」と「街の魔法」の２種類があり、MP的なものが別にある。

プレイヤーの魔法は画面上の青色ゲージで見れる専用MPを使い、マップの好きな場所に空襲のごとく投下する。時間だけが回復条件なので無暗な連射をせず一発でかっこよく決めよう。奇跡の安売りはできぬのだ。そのぶんちゃんと場所を考えるとすっごい強烈。

「街の魔法」は要するに電気みたいなもんで、クリスタルを燃料に発電し建物ごとにMPを管理している。でも敵が死ぬと魂を吸って回復するあたり魔法。一発はショボいけど物量を増やてフルオートなのが魅力。
汚物を消毒するファイアボルトタワーが基本になってる。発電が足りないとファイアボルトの連射が悲しいことになる。

遊んでみて難しいと思う人はデフォルトのサバイバルモードからピースフルモードに切り替えれば魔物が劇的に減るので楽。
ただしサバイバルの世界とピースフルの世界はLINBOが別なので簡単には養殖させてくれない。おのれ開発。でもなんか納得した。

So you could set up a couple towers near the points of regular conflict and it would give them a little flow of health. This, or just making the healing aura more powerful would work. Differentiating between friendlies and enemy health - maybe its just me, because i'm slightly colorblind, but I have a hard time telling the difference between the health bars when theres one of those massive heaps of blood and fire. It'd be cool if the health bars were drastically different in the color, or if a colorblind mode was added so you could have complementary colors, making them complete opposites. 

In conclusion, this game is fucking awesome. When you get that flow of essence to your cullis gate, essence collectors, and firebolt towers... it just feels and looks amazing because theres all this power cycling through the map. Its a great way to show how everything is being fueled and refueled. After a successful night without any casualties, you feel like you did your godly job well. But its hard to get that job done because the people you rule are morons. Nevertheless, I would definitely recommend getting this game just so you can master your setup and understand whats most important. That way, once the devs to add in more complicated mechanics, you'll have all the basics completely down. Otherwise you'll just be thrown in later on with a LOT to learn. 

9001/10 stars.

So, how do you go about reviewing an Early Access Game?
I think the best way is to measure the improvements to the game over a course of a few weeks.

[h1]When I bought the game[/h1]
It was little more than a tech demo with a lot of bugs. It only had 3 or so ressources, awkward villager management and not many things to build. I was constantly overrun by zombies, there was little balancing.

[h1]Now that I´m writing this review[/h1]
Over the past weeks the game has been updated on a regular basis, bugs fixed and content added. The community is being involved in the developement process.
The game has a much more differentiated interface and villager statistics. A ressource refinement system has been added, the magic ressource 'crystal' is now usable and powers some of your buildings. The balancing has improved a lot in a way that you actually have a chance to survive. Monsters have been added and others balanced. Most of the ressources are renewable now. You can already call it a game at this point, it is playable up to end-game without major disruptions in the gameplay.

[h1]What to expect from this game[/h1]You get an indie survival game with tower defense as well as rpg elements. Build up your medieval fantasy village and try to survive the neverending undead onslaught.

Still being early access, the game has a lot of potential to go in many directions.
More towers could be added, like electric or acid, dealing splash/aoe damage, or to target specific monsters with weaknesses to certain damage types.
A crafting system could be added to bring out the rpg side, allowing armor and weapons, or a profession system like warriors, mages, archers.

What I´d really like to see are more maps. Maybe a community map contest?

[h1]Pricing[/h1]
At the current stage, being in early access, I find the price a bit high, since the user doesn´t get the finished game yet. In my opinion early access games should reward buying it/taking the risk in this stage.
If the game continues on it´s path the price will be justified for the final release.

It is a race against time to try and stay safe while the zombies and skeletons spawn (the monster spawning is going through some big changes in the current cycles so I left this a bit vague).

[h1]Review of Indie Developer Raymond Doerr[/h1](scroll down for game review)

[h1]Review of Retro-Pixel Castles[/h1][b]Current Version: Indev12c[/b]
(Pro/Con lists are not my style, hope you like to read)

[b]Influences[/b]
On the Steam Store Page, the game is marked as having several noticable influences, but in its current version, I mainly  agree with three of them, and I'll try to break them down.

[b]Dwarf Fortress:[/b] This is the most obvious influence in my opinion (and also the closest game to ever touch upon what I want in a DF-like game), You have practically zero control over your villagers. You can place buildings to be constructed when your villagers get to it (although in a generally predictable manner), set resource harvesting tasks, and assign free (random) villagers to work at certain buildings. That's about it for control right now, and where most of the DF influence stops. P.S. "Losing is Fun!" theme is well-intact in Retro-Pixel Castles.

[b]Banished:[/b] You start the game on whatever map you choose with nothing but a bunch of villagers and are free to choose where you place your Village Center (required before you can build anything else and serves as radial zone for where you can place other buildings at first, so choose wisely!), unless someone (or you!) has made a map where the Village Center was already placed (you only get one, this ain't no 4x). Also, when you build your first farm, you have to collect wild food (carrots only, so far) before they can start growing them in the farm (this is a one-time deal, a working farm can populate a new one). While it is ultimately a village sim and has buildings, food/energy requirements, I'd end the tracable influences to Banished there.

[b]Tower Defense:[/b] This is a big one, as it encompasses the actual challenge of the game. I spend most of my time on Peaceful, because I'm a casual grow-and-love city builder type gamer, but this is one of the rare few games where I'll switch off peaceful and play the regular game because A) Peaceful at this stage is -super- low on content and extremely easy being locked on Day 1 difficulty (you really only need/will ever use 2-4 of the available building types) B) Instead of devoting my city to raising a military, in Tower Defense style, your buildings do most of the work for you (your villagers will fight mobs, dumbly, and you will lose a lot of them, but that's the point! "Losing is Fun!"). Also, currently, you get to have one save, per mode, per map, per profile (you really only need one profile, unless you have a family or RL friends -scoff-) so I can come back to my peaceful cities when I want. So far (more buildings planned in the next update, expect this to change), the only offensive building is a Fire Tower (you can also build walls for defense/mob funneling) which will TD-style automatically fire at mobs close enough. All living things die in a burst of pixelated blood and green "essence" which serves as mana/power for your Fire Tower (and an Essence Collector, which is essentially a battery for the Fire Tower). Every day that you survive, the rate that mobs appear increases, and so the difficulty.

Most of the game and its mechanics are covered above.

[b]Atmosphere:[/b]
[b]Pixels!:[/b] At this point, you either love pixel-art or hate it. If you love it, this game does it very well. There's even an option to smooth out some of the pixel animation like essence flowing to an Essence Collector/Fire Tower(which looks gorgeous and well-fantasy-themed even for pixels), but I like pixels so I haven't even bothered. I'll edit this next time I go into the game and look (which may not be til the next update).

[b]Music/Sound:[/b] Music is a nice, calming fantasy-like tune that fits well into the pixel-art world. I've never had to turn it down or off after several hours, but that's really all I have to say about it, as I tend to not notice game music anyways. Sounds come mainly from birth/death of villagers and are just a quick happy or sad tune that fits with the music-style.

[b]Maps:[/b]
[b]You can make your own maps![/b] Saved in whatever, and however many, folders you'd like. Ray is currently not very focused on (or very impressive at - sorry man) making maps for the game himself, which brings me to a special point.
[b]If you buy Early Access and you make a good map and post it on his forum, Ray may add your map to the game before final release![/b] This is, as far as it stands now, an Early-Access-Only feature. I've seen those threads pop up, and I've seen maps get added, and updated. Be a real contributor to the game!
Maps are 1-z level (no digging down DF fans, these are humans!) but give a vague impression of depth as dense resources appear "taller" than their regular counterparts and is a nice touch to the aesthetic without complicated mechanics needed.
Currently, Ray is experimenting with map size in an effort to reduce code/program efficiency, so if you get in now, there might be changes.

I played it a while and i have to say it shows promise.
What i missed from similar games like Banished was a challenge from monsters or enemies. Like other tribes trying to kill my people or simply wild animals. Banished couldnt fulfill this wish but Retro Pixel Castles does. Although till now it is limited to Slimes and Zombies (more to come).
Obviously it is Early Access and not finished, it is in many ways very barebone, has at the moment no saving function (end 2014) and misses many other things in terms of controls, layout and look.
But it also is very playable i have to say. There is something you can get out and giving you some fun. Maps are available from the developer (although they are a bit ugly) or you get a community created map (looking much better).
Steamworkshop is missing till now, which makes these a bit "harder" to obtain, but they are there.

The game goes a similar direction Banished goes. You start with a bunch of people, you create a Towncenter, harvest ressources and build other buildings to support your people or get defenses against Monsters up.
You cant control your people directly, which often is a bit painful because you also cant give other commands like a rallye point or make a priority to a building, so you cant influence till now which building they start to build or where they shall group up to fight and defend their town. Also a more direct control over single townsmen/women would be a good addition to decide who is going to be a builder and who will be a farmer (or maybe a guard later on?).

Playing on one map is very different than on the next one. Even playing several times on the same map is a variety in experience because the starting points are randomized.

12677201.review:
A magnificent attention to detail went into the textures for this game! With several variations for each object or tile, nothing in the map looks quite like the copy-and-paste wireframe you usually expect to see in other 2D pixel games. Down to the last blade of grass, there seems to be a nice variety of different shades, shapes and directions each individual block displays - with every texture having a decorative secondary layer for its own material type. Complementing the game's surprisingly vibrant and lively textures is an amazing, hand-crafted lighting system ruled over by some of the other textures and objects, and a fully functional day-and-night cycle. Torches provide a light source, lava illuminates a small radius of land around it, and crystals glow in the dark like fireflies. Every wall and object has a dynamic and intricate reaction to which direction the sun is in relation to the world below (as well as other light sources), which changes gradually as the day cycle goes by. Even the water shines in the night as the moon reflects down on it! 

While this may not sound like much to most modern gamers, for a pixel-based game, the way this is handled is extremely impressive, and adds a clever illusion of 3D with a very nice shadow system. Even some of the world textures are crafted with certain curves around the edges and changes of width that add a realistic sense of direction and angle. This is most visible in the game's own main menu, with the stone-brick wall trim which boxes us in the game's window. 

The game currently is still in a very early alpha stage and offers no enemies or immediate dangers beyond the starvation of your villagers who wander around aimlessly like hilarious morons until you lay out the foundation for a town hall and send out vague and indirect orders for different resources - a feature true to its own advertisement. This game is definitely no standard RTS, as you have much less control over what happens within the world, instead treating the villagers like ants in an antfarm. You give them basic instructions and a general goal in life, and they immediately begin deciding amongst themselves who works where and who gathers or builds what. 

Villagers marry and house themselves independently (assuming there had already been homes built, by your command) and have their own unique set of attributes such as Strength and Dexterity, which increase depending on how hard they work or how long they travel. If they are over-worked or if a spouse dies, a villager will become extremely depressed, and lose the will and the energy to continue working at full capacity for a short period of time. Eventually, the villager will find relief in rest or another lover, and so will continue on with his or her life.  

The lack of direct control over your villagers is a very welcome and unique change of flow from your average city-building sim, as it gives you a very relaxed and non-competitive or war-driven experience. While I'm sure more threats will be introduced further down the line, the general concept of the game so far is very interesting and humble. I personally have never seen a game concept quite like this, and despite my lack of interest in pixel-based games, I found this quite enjoyable. Even with its current lack of content. 

This is still a very early build, with a lot of features and content to be added as time goes by. As for right now though, in the state it's in at the time, it comes with a refreshing breath of life in the world of sandbox sims.  Where other games force linear and challenging objectives  or goals, this game's only real objective is survival, and determining how to best accomplish this, with strategy. The gameplay itself reminds me somewhat of Lemmings and Black & White, two gems from Lionhead Studios and Team17. One an objective-based RTS sim where you give general orders to minions in order to help them escape a maze, and the other a god-game where you do your best to keep a strong and stable economy and gain control over other villages. All in all, Retro-Pixel Castles comes with an /exceptionally/ nice soundtrack which really helps set the mood and clear the mind, and a surprising amount of detail and clarity in its world textures which promises a great deal of polish in the final product. The lighting and 3D-like illusions shown in 2D textures makes the game almost remind me a little of Don't Starve, with its ability to turn a simple 2D world into something more like a pop-out storybook. To know that all this comes from such a small dev team is very thrilling, and I would definitely like to see what direction this project takes in the future.

I don't want to go into little bugs and irritants, although they are not in short supply, this is early access and these are expected, but the above problems aren't something you can fix with a little patch, they require major reworkings of the game or the way the development operates.

By far the biggest issue here is the way new villagers are aquired; the game borrows the double dumbass approach of towns where you will only reproduce if your people are happy AND your people will only be happy if they aren't doing anything. I really didn't want to add this sentence but if you look in the comments for this review it's obvious i'm going to get called on it if i don't so yes, technically you CAN aquire new citizens even at 0 happiness, but the odds of that happening are so abysmally low, i've played 4 games now and i've seen 1 new person appear at <25 happiness, so it doesn't matter.

This is made far worse by the game's approach to combat. I expect combat to change a lot as new features are planned for it, but it is still taking the approach of high volatility combat; you're going to lose people defending your home. Compare this to Towns and Dwarf Fortress; in towns you also have this stupid villager approach to population growth, but you're very unlikely to lose people in combat, so it doesn't completely shut down your village even if you're frequently in combat. Dwarf fortress has frequent, massive genocides with scores of dead characters, but population growth is tied to the value of all items your fort owns, and looting enemies gives you lots of weapons, armor and clothes of good value, so you typically get lots of new migrants coming in to refill the ranks of your military.

This game has you attacked about every 30 seconds right now, there is practically no breathing room, and it starts immediately. The game seems more like an RTS than a village sim, but with an extremely slow process of replenishing your forces. This could work in the same ways as custom maps for starcraft and warcraft have done, which was awesome, but when you can't expand your population you're just stuck, unable to do anything.

Tying happiness to idling is another total failure for the game, especially with the constant aggression. You basically turn the whole game into ballancing workload vs free time; too little workload and you won't be able to build the defenses, too much workload and you never get enough people. This could work as a component to the game, but it just becomes the sole focus, and all you end up doing is unassigning and reassigning people in a neverending circle of tedius micromanagement.

Speaking of tedius micromanagement, the villagers are terrible at carrying out tasks efficiently. If you order too many houses/defenses/farms (read: more than 2) they'll start building the first house, then when it's halfway done, they apparently switch to the next, with just a few people working on the first. The result is a collage of unfinished structures littering your town, and if you're building defenses while they're being attacked, the builders will drop their materials to fight, then carry them of to the wrong building, leaving a single unfinished tower for up to 20 minutes was the worst i had, with the little idiots running back to pick up their wood, then drop it as a zombie got close, run over to punch the zombie, then pick up the wood and haul it to another tower under construction. (I queued 4 towers, silly me)

This isn't really a big issue to work around, just don't queue up constructions, right? Sure, but this is more micromanagement on top of giving builders their mandatory vacation time, and on top of the next issue:

Villagers apparently gather resources from completely random places. This means if you're building something in one place and you assign them to gather wood/rocks nearby, they'll gather it there, but if you then build the next building somewhere else (Why would anyone want to keep their farms and defenses seperate...?) you have to unassign where to gather resources, or the idiots will run halfway across the map to chop down a tree, instead of the one assigned right next to them. 

All this combined means you don't spend your time organizing defenses, planning your town or anything you'd expect from this game, you're just babysitting these idiotic villagers; go chop here, don't chop there, don't be a builder, don't mine there, mine here, be a builder, don't be a farmer, etc. etc. and this is what the game is; it takes hours to build anything because of this nonsense, and you need to leave the game running without building anything to get new villagers.

The other major issue with this as a village sim is that there are no different resources; just food and construction materials. Wood and stone are just different colours; no buildings/tools/tech needed for extraction, take the same time, trees don't regrow, what's the point?

The game's bussiness practice also smells bad. The game was initially kickstarted successfully, and IMMEDIATELY after that it was dumped on early access, despite being nothing more than an abysmal tech demo; no combat, just farms and houses forever; 30 minutes and the game ran out of things to do. My problem with this is how eager the dev is for cash. Why wasn't the kickstarter enough to at least make a functional game before throwing it out here? He'll happily charge full price for a tech demo, and the "game" has even been on sale. I hate old sayings, but "Don't sell the skin before shooting the bear" seems apt for once.

The other problem the dev has is the game's lack of focus. This game is NOT on early access to get feedback, because there are so many features missing it's practically impossible to give any worthwhile feedback. What the dev seems to want is ideas for where to take his game, and early access is a terrible place for that. Maybe you want a village sim and this turns into an RTS? Well then, jokes on you. It's impossible to satisfy everyone, but you're still charging them for it. Like i wrote at first, the game has elements of an RTS and a village sim as the dev advertises both on the store page and here: http://retropixelcastles.com/index.php?/page/key_features.html but they don't work together. You can't have the volatility of an RTS combined with the slow growth of a village sim; one has to dominate. The game also touts this "inevitable failure" part, as if it has any benefit; If you're building a village you want to see it grow and expand; what's the point of that if the village doesn't matter and you're just playing for high score? I don't mind the "see how long you can last" thing, but its fun in an RTS, where you build things only because of their immediate value to your survival, not in a village sim. 

Apparently we're supposed to unlock stuff after we die, because grinding for necessary unlocks is everyone's favorite thing about videogames.

The game also claims to be "unique" which is nonsense; stronghold and majesty has done "defend and grow village" over a decade ago, and MUCH better. 

TL;DR: This is an RTS where all you can build is farms, houses and towers, and you can't control or replenish your units.
